summary: In the 1930s, the Grand Budapest Hotel is a popular European ski resort, presided over by concierge Gustave H. (Ralph Fiennes). Zero, a junior lobby boy, becomes Gustave's friend and protege. Gustave prides himself on providing first-class service to the hotel's guests, including satisfying the sexual needs of the many elderly women who stay there. When one of Gustave's lovers dies mysteriously, Gustave finds himself the recipient of a priceless painting and the chief suspect in her murder.

reviews.content: Wonderful style and mode of storytelling by performances that more than fit and aspects that more than entertain.
I really liked this one, it was sad, funny, hearwarming... It was an amazing movie with very good set design and photography, I loved how it was show. Really liked it.
The best definition of Wes Anderson movies.

"The Grand Budapest Hotel" is a delightful film that is equal parts charming and quirky. The movie boasts a star-studded cast, including Ralph Fiennes, Tilda Swinton, and Bill Murray, who bring the eccentric characters to life in a hilarious and heartwarming way. The cinematography is stunning, and the set design transports you to a whimsical and colorful world that is both nostalgic and fantastical. The plot is clever and engaging, weaving together humor, suspense, and emotion seamlessly. While the movie may not be everyone's cup of tea, it is undoubtedly a must-see for fans of Wes Anderson's unique style of filmmaking. Overall, I would highly recommend "The Grand Budapest Hotel" for its exceptional performances, stunning visuals, and compelling storyline.
cinematic masterpiece! Absolute must see

A model staple of Wes Anderson cinematography, it has all the charm, humor and wit one would expect from Anderson himself. An ensemble cast as well to pull it off, The Grand Budapest Hotel is a 10/10 must see.

This is a masterpiece by Wes Anderson and by far one of the best piece of art. 
It should be included in one of the best movies of the century.

Great movie, fun from the whole thing. Sad tho how in some moments the vfx or the miniatures take you off the movie. Beside that, its great for beggining to end. The speed of the script and scenes its so good and it complement with the urgency of the characters. The story its so simple but you sympathize with the characters and you understand the reasons for every decidion, and acting just GREAT!
A very Wes Anderson film, had some good moments, loved the cast. I'm sure it was a very good film, but just not my type I think.

GRAND BUDAPEST is definitely one of Wes Anderson's better films, wherein style, atmosphere, themes and compelling characters all elevate each other. Zany, charming, yet not without depth, the film drags a bit during the third act, thanks to a somewhat convoluted plot, but never loses its internal coherence.
This movie is LOL hilarious but you don't dare LOL because you'll miss something!  It's so full of everything! EVERYTHING! Just watch it! You've never seen anything like it!
The film has pulled out the military in terms of direction, and the intelligent story and the cast full of personalities make it an enjoyable film.
Cast is superb, intelligently written and acted.  It's as though the actors begged to have even a small part in this movie.  It's different, but great.
One needs to watch every Wes Anderson's movie more than once..to truly appreciate. Great cast so one can watch it dozen times and not get bored.
Highly stylish as if like a well-crafted picture book. Maybe not for everyone but sure that worth watching just for the visual. Great use of ensemble cast and they are excellent.

I never thought I'd like the style of movies Wes Anderson makes but I really liked this movie. It has great acting and it's a great story, but Andersons distinct style is what made is special and actually what I liked most about it. I'll definetly be checking out his other films.

One of my favourite films of all time.
Incredible performances, incredible music, incredibly aesthetic.
When people describe films as art this is what they mean. Its hard to put into words, just go see it.

the comedy in this movie is really good and it's not just a normie 2001 type of jokes, I really love the "awkward silence" type of humor in this movie, the only downside I can find is that the green screen and the cgi is really noticeable but idk if that's intentional or not. Overall good ending and an amazing movie to watch while laying on your couch with a coffee in hand on a sunday morning.

One of my favorites. Great cast. Upbeat. And the color palette is breathtaking. The use of color ALONE in this movie elevates it from a fun Wes Anderson movie to one of his best. And the performances are excellent.

My favourite Wes Anderson movie, probably in my top 5 movies of all time. Beautiful scenery, a funny & chaotic yet melancholy plot line, engaging characters. Felt completely fresh and different, such a unique movie in a world of endless remakes.

Filled with endearing characters, great actors, lots of action and plot twists, beautiful cinematography and hilarious jokes, this fast-paced movie may be hard to follow in some moments, but at the end, it leads to many awesome action scenes. A must-watch that you'll want to watch again and again.

Wes Anderson was able to craft one of, if not the most entertaining movies of all time. The uniqueness of Anderson's filmmaking, the satisfying cinematography, the dialogue, and the beautiful set design. It all comes together perfectly. On top of the genius filmmaking of Wes Anderson, he was able to work with one of the best casts in a movie. Ralph Fiennes is fantastic and proves as to why he is one of greatest actors working today. Tony Revolori is perfect for his role and plays it so well. Adrien Brody, Willem Dafoe, Tilda Swinton, Edward Norton, Saoirse Ronan, and Jeff Goldblum are all fantastic and their minor roles. I could go on and on about how great this movie is. Overall, if you want to watch a very fast paced and entertaining movie, I highly recommend The Grand Budapest Hotel.

82%: October 2022. Lots of great actors with small roles. Well done film. Great acting and a good story. Nothing too captivating that would get this score much higher. Would rewatch but no big need to.

When I got recommended to watch this movie I thought it was going to be boring. It was the complete opposite! This funny and thrilling movie is great to watch when wanting to watch a comedy movie. I have seen this movie many times and won't stop now!
so good, how is it possible to be such a great movie holy fuck
Brilliant performance by Ralph Fiennes and a stellar cast
The best movie screenplay ever written! With the best production design ever made in a movie! And the best movie costumes ever designed!

It's themes may not mesh together at times and i was a bit confused at times due to certain dialogue structure and elements of the plot, The Grand Budapest Hotel is once again a phenomenal achievement by Wes Anderson, who wrote and directed this film with total mastery of his own craft; a very unconventionally told narrative with loads of humor, with and emotion and containing a lot of exciting moments and immersive performances.

Where do I start?? I wanted to check this movie out because of the cast alone, all of whom I love a lot. Not only was it great seeing them all together but they acted fantastic, especially Ralph Fiennes who has some of the best line delivery I've ever seen him execute in any of his films, and he always performs just right for his roles. When it started, it took a little bit to get the plot going and lost my interest a couple of times but then it grabbed my attention as it progressed more! It had its own flavor and was shot very well too, and visually/style-wise it looked great! The humor mostly worked and I'm glad that I ended up not regretting watching it!
One of the best-made movies of all time. It's difficult to find a fault but the advantages are so numerous that I cannot run out.
I dont give many movies 5 stars but this one is just so good. The camera work, the chapter frames, the acting, the colours, the music, the story just everything about this movie is perfect for me.

Laughably overrated junk film made for the sole purpose of plugging the mainstream WWII/holocaust narratives. An impertinence, since the audience likely isn't expecting it here, and certainly didn't sign up for it. More kosher Hollywood social engineering couched within a mediocre "movie".

A wonderous cinematic experience. Wes Anderson direction make the film stunningly beautiful to look at and the quick execution of its dialogue works perfectly. This combination of wit and visuals veers into the absurd on multiple occasions but considering the story's format this only enhances the experience. The cast is great across the board and Ralph Fiennes delivers the performance of a lifetime - he is truly captivation in this role. I also really like the nostalgic and melancholic tone, it's very well balanced with the comedy.
Loved this! Lighthearted with a good storyline. Well acted too.

Wes Anderson's best film yet! This film shows what sets Anderson apart from other directors, taking him from a competent filmmaker to an auteur, with many of his signature tropes used throughout, exciting the his fans as the man they know and love creates yet another cinematic masterpiece. The film uses comedy which fits the tone of the film perfectly, being careful not to overuse jokes. The fragmented narrative is done to perfection, Tarentino esque with everything just working out amazingly. I was gripped throughout the film although I felt the narrative was confusing in places, it excited me as I wanted to figure out what was going to happen next, showing the skill of Anderson and his pure brilliance as a director and a master of suspense. Anderson's unique way of telling a story always has me, along with most of the audience, in awe at how brilliant he is, especially his use of color and symmetry in every shot. This amount of effort which he puts into his films pays off as he always pulls in large audiences and box office ratings, cementing himself as one of the all-time great story tellers.
A strong movie, one of Wes Anderson's better ones, though by now his pastel-soaked shtick is starting to wear thin.

So visually pleasing .

While some accuse the ilk of Wes Anderson as putting greater import on style over substance, and though of course this film bleeds style in every frame, the beautiful and provocative story does not fail to entrance and charm. Brilliant performances, especially by Ralph Fiennes, accompany a wonderful score, smart cinematography, and the distinctively lustrous and warm use of color and lighting. A gorgeous and well executed film.

This is a prime example of a movie that I have virtually no problems with, but just didn't quite do it for me. All of the real performances were genuinely good. It deserved all of its Oscar wins (Fiennes deserved at least a nom). The cinematography and score were both excellent. The majority of the comedy landed. Anderson had an interesting directorial style, etc. But like I said, it didn't quite do it for me. I don't really know why. Definitely worth watching, I don't have a bad word to say about this movie.

The Grand Budapest Hotel is a film by Wes Anderson filled with his intricacies and kirks about a crime mystery involving Mosieur Gustave a concierge at the Grand Budapest Hotel played by Ralph Fiennes and his lobby boy played by Tony Revolori, This movie is quite crazy at times and has a huge emsemble cast including Tilda Swinton, Jeff Goldblum, F. Murray Abraham, Adrien Brody, Willem Dafoe, and many others. Ralph Fiennes is charming and funny on this role and carries this movie almost by himself. The plot is interesting and keep us wondering where is all gonna go and end up. The comedy is typical Wes Anderson so it does not always hit for me but the script is really good and his typical use of miniatures is really good here too. In the end is a fun well made film that's quite strange which is typical Wes Anderson.
A film that rewards it's viewer time and time again
This movie was funny, witty and had amazing camera work, it's not as good as Treasure Planet but it was pretty close

I say this because if you are relaxed, at home, quiet day with a full focus you are gonna enjoy every detail of this film.. its art.. the locations, the acting, the cast the plot, and everything is so well executed.. i was surprised to see so many famous actors who I like even taking a small role being so big nowadays.. the plot was great..  the cast of the 2 main characters was perfect.. love the chemistry...   as a viwers whoenjoys but analizes films while they are happeing.  was left with need to understand more at the end.. Fun, visually appealing, and distinct in almost every way. And for better or for worse, everything seems very particularly put together.
Absolutely amazing work from Wes Anderson! The colour, narrative and characters are all amazingly constructed and perfectly guide the story along

Technically speaking, the best achievement of Anderson.
The Texan director definitively proves to be one of the most talented storytellers around, creating a brilliant and fairy comedy, filtered by three interlocutors (if we include the reader we see in the first scene) depicted by as many different color palettes and aspect ratios.
It is precisely the love for stories and the benefit of the doubt about their veracity (improbability) that make "The Grand Budapest Hotel" a film that differs from most of the US production, which never hides the artificiality of cinema medium, making immediately clear that what we are watching is a staging, a skillfully crafted work. 
The awareness of the artistic medium as artifice and the frankness of its exhibition, are two of the strengths of the Anderson aesthetic and, maybe unconsciously, the main reasons for the idiosyncrasy by a part of the public.
The pastel palette, another distinctive trait of his aesthetic, is used to create a unique and inimitable imaginary; lacking, however, of that emotional transport we can find in some previous works such as "The Royal Tenenbaums" and "The Darjeeling Limited".
It is difficult to be able to identify with the characters, who become more and more caricatured and flat due the author's continuous search for technical and narrative perfection.
But "The Grand Budapest Hotel" is sincere, and not as pretentious as it may seem at first glance: Anderson does not want to replicate something that already exists, he does not want to limit himself to emulations or imitations of some kind, but he desires to model an entire macrocosm from scratch, decorated and packaged like a Mendl's pastry.

The Grand Budapest Hotel looks like a fairytale inside of a snow globe with hints of fomenting fascism. Visually, it's a pastel wonder that although fictional, is based on the coziness that exudes from Central European Christmastime. It's a display of Wes Anderson's style, with perfectly framed and centered shots of pop, pop, pop dialogue that could take place inside of a dollhouse. This is a comprehensive story concerning swindling, high-brow art, inheritance, nostalgia, injustice, the "immigrant story," and Nazism (albeit, a fictionalized version of it). Anderson takes you from 1985 to 1968 to the 1930s with his multi-layered storytelling. The ensemble cast is fantastic and includes the usual Andersonian suspects — Owen Wilson, Willem Dafoe, Bill Murray, Adrian Brody, Edward Norton, et al. — but all of these actors hold minor roles. The undeniable star is Ralph Fiennes as the loyal concierge, Msr. Gustave H. I didn't appreciate his performance when I had first seen this one back in the mid-2010s. It's such a distinct performance than his notable roles in Schindler's List, Red Dragon, Spider, Quiz Show, In Bruges, et al. In fact, I don't see a movie before TGBH where he'd have done anything similar. Truly, a testament to his range. "Gunther was slain in the catacombs" is the sort of line that, in context, grasps the quintessence of this character. It makes you feel good to watch even when it's covering some pretty dark material. I love this movie. Haven't seen French Dispatch yet, but this is definitely Wes Anderson's finest.
A truly artistic, witty, fun, & emotional ride.  What else to say but this is why I go to the Movies.
Sonic is lord lord king lord

It is genuinely different from all the movies I have watched. The director really uses his visual skills in color palettes, camera work, cinematography, and visual styles. Overall, a visually stunning film.
Genuinely just incredible

The Grand Budapest Hotel is practically perfect: the plot is eye-catching, linear and manages to surprise in several points. The only problem (for me) were the first 5 minutes of part 1...I was tempted to take away the film because it seemed all redundant, fortunately the film is shooting great and keeps you glued to the screen for 1h and 40m

The acting was truly phenomenal aswell. Such a well-rounded movie. The humour as well fit so well with the tone of the movie. Exceptionally well done!
the best movie ever made

Another one of Anderson's richest, deepest and most hilarious outputs. It's moving, while still being absurd and featuring some beautiful set design. I knew I liked this one before, but somehow I had forgotten just how much this one had me pissing myself throughout the whole thing.

One of my favourite movies of all time. Wes does a brilliant job of bringing together an amazing cast with a great narrative, and keeps it gripping throughout. I love the music and sound effects that come with the amazing acting. Ralph Fiennes does a phenomenal job! Must see!

That it was directed by Wes Anderson (who has a unique style that really fascinates, but admittedly not everybody will like or warm to his style) and that the cast is so stellar were reasons enough to see 'The Grand Budapest Hotel' in the first place, as well as its many accolades and critical acclaim.

While it isn't quite flawless, and it is easy to see why a number of people don't like or will not like it (due to a lot of the cast's roles being pretty short, only Gustave and Zero being fully fleshed out of the characters and those who have a problem with Anderson's style), 'The Grand Budapest Hotel' is a visually stunning, hugely entertaining, wonderfully weird and impeccably cast and acted film.

It really stuns visually, with cinematography that is not only clever in technique but also gorgeous in aesthetic and tight, fluid editing. The costumes, production design and hair and make-up richly deserved their Oscar/Academy Award wins, the costume and production design have a lusciously colourful fairy-tale feel while also given substance by the bleakly atmospheric quality that reflects the crime drama aspect of the story brilliantly.

Alexandre Desplat also received an Oscar, and with its hauntingly hypnotic and entrancing tones it richly deserved it as to me it was by far the best score of those nominated. Anderson directs superbly, the story balances darkness and quirkiness to great effect (the prison scene is unforgettable) and it's never too simplistic or convoluted (though of course the visuals, dialogue and performances make much more of an impact) and the screenplay is a sublime mixture of the dark, the quirky, the witty and the subtle delivered with rapid-fire.

'The Grand Budapest Hotel' boasts an impeccable cast and pretty much everybody does a splendid job, though many of the roles are short. My only criticism of the film is that Harvey Keitel and Saoirse Ronan are underused and just get lost amongst everything else, an unrecognisable Tilda Swinton also has little to do but still gives a bat-out-of-hell performance.

Bill Murray, F. Murray Abraham, Jeff Goldblum, Jason Schwartzman and Owen Wilson give very entertaining performances, while Edward Norton is delightfully droll and Adrien Brody and especially Willem Dafoe bring sinister foreboding to the film. Some may say that Tony Revolori is overshadowed by the more experienced cast members (being the only newcomer in a large cast of big names), but to me he more than holds his own and effectively plays it straight. The film belongs to Ralph Fiennes, in what is essentially the heart of the film, while he has always been a fine actor he has not given a performance this brilliant in years, never knew he could be so riotously funny.

In conclusion, a wonderful film and a hotel well worth revisiting more than once if to one's taste. 9/10 Bethany Cox

top 3 favorite movies all time.

Wes anderson is soOooOo good.

I'm very glad I got to see this unique masterpiece of cinema. Unfortunately, I saw it many years after it came out, but nevertheless, I got to see it. The film is pure eye candy to look at. I think Wes Anderson is a brilliant creative mind—this film was about as Wes Anderson as Wes Anderson can Wes Anderson. I thought it was a very clever screenplay, the visual palette was gorgeous, and Ralph Fiennes and the young Tony Revolori gave great individual performances. The movie felt a bit "much" at times, but I think there's a definite time, place, and mood for Wes Anderson. I liked this one, it was fun.

What can I say? I'm a sucker for Wes Anderson films and this one had it all; murder, war, love, assassinations, bobsledding, cats, prison... all the absurdities one would expect from Anderson and an amazingly stacked cast. Ralph Fiennes and Tony Revolori were an unlikely, but incredibly likeable duo. I wanted to be a part of their friendship/mentorship/family. In true Wes Anderson fashion, heavy themes of grief, death, belonging, identity and love were explored through the symmetrical lens of color and wit. The Royal Tennebaums still holds the first place Wes Anderson spot for me personally, but this is a close second. In the words of the great Reading Rainbow, 'Don't take my word for it!' - Watch this movie! It's a great adventure.
Wes Anderson at its best. Visually inspired, charming, funny and heartbreaking.
Boring plot. Pretentious stuff. Pure and simple emptiness aesthetics in times of Instagram.
Perfectly planned an executed by a visionary who's creativity is only surpassed by God himself. A star studded cast and probably the only place you can see green goblin duel  Voldemort.
Great plot, funny slapstick and brilliantly shot.

I hate Wes Anderson and his stupid movies. But from a visual perspective, this is probably as good as it gets. There are a couple of hilarious parts that make this a watchable movie. TRUE RATING = 70/100

Highly entertaining, emotionally resonant, and appealing in every sense of that word, "The Grand Budapest Hotel" truly lives up to its marvelous name due to Wes Anderson's signature touch and the actors' dedication to their roles. The entire film from start to finish feels like a masterful work of art, and the end result is a masterpiece that sticks with you well after the credits begin rolling. The atmosphere presented feels oddly calming and relaxing, the humor is done to perfection, and the story is compelling. The characters, though at times there may seem to be too many, are all done very well. Overall, a film that I absolutely loved and would highly recommend to anyone that is curious in this film.
Off-beat imagery, good story telling and great acting. This is one of those special movies that is hard to compare to anything else.
I really enjoyed the colours and visuals. The world Wes Anderson can create is amazing. Great camerawork. But the plot didn't really satisfy me which was a disappointment.

The Grand Budapest Hotel is a Crime/Adventure film produced by Wes Anderson in 2014. It takes place in a fictional town, Zubrowka in 1932 between the wars. In this film, we follow the story of Zero Moustafa who was hired as a lobby boy by M. Gustave, the owner of The Grand Budapest Hotel. After a rich woman, one of M. Gustave's lovers, Madame D mysteriously dies, we follow the adventures of Zero to help M. Gustave escape from being framed and to solve the mystery of who killed her.

A single aspect of the film that stood out to me was the usage of the cameras when filming. Rather than the camera following the actors or leading the actors, the camera was mostly static. This made the film stand out and funny in a sense. It also gave it a more storytelling view which was what the film is based on. Having a static camera that stayed in one place also brought out many small details in the film that you wouldn't usually see in many other films. The usage of a static camera angle presented the many small details showing in this film combined with its storytelling aspect is genius.

Wes Anderson's film, The Grand Budapest Hotel takes on a mystery aspect while giving you a few laughs. I would give this film a solid 4.5/5 just because I liked it. The film was funny and very entertaining.
Love the colors and the Actors in the Movie the story Is not my Favorite Wes Anderson  Movie but will always recommend to see to see inside the mind of this artist. Saoirse Ronan!!

The Grand Budapest Hotel (2014) directed by Wes Anderson is an adventurous comedy. Gustave H. (Raph Fiennes) is a well-renowned concierge at the Grand Budapest Hotel amidst a war in the 1930s. Gustave is known for making "friendships" with the older wealthy women that stay at the hotel. Unfortunately, one of the women Gustave H. is well acquainted with suddenly dies. Gustave H. and Zero (Tony Revolori), his lobby boy in training, travel to the old women's funeral and Gustave H. is gifted with an extremely important painting. Due to its popularity, Gustave H. is framed for the old women's murder and he must attempt to clear his name

Throughout this film, symmetry catches the eyes of the audience. Wes Anderson does this by not only keeping the camera in the center but also placing chairs, tables, people even, on either side of the camera. If you were to draw a vertical line down the middle of the screen both sides would be balanced. Something is satisfying in knowing that the background, or setting, being shown is perfect when the character and what they are going through is far from it. The color palette that is used throughout the film highlight how life is seen inside and outside of the hotel. Because of the war, the are lots of blues, grays, and browns. This highlights the ruggedness of the war.  In the hotel, the colors are more vibrant due to its popularity. The colors purple, pink, and red give the hotel a whimsical feel. What I enjoyed about this film is that it focuses on the artistry of the film. Wes Anderson uses actors that do amazing jobs, therefore as the director, he can focus on the colors, camera, and the overall aesthetic of the film.

I would recommend this movie and all Wes Anderson films for that matter. This story that he gives us in this film is filled with drama and adventure that has a bittersweet ending. The dialogue is also witty and funny with a hint of adult language. The fact that it is being narrated by two different people in different eras is what makes this film feel a bit more real. Yet the cinematography keeps a childlike element that doesn't take focus away from the acting. This film has enough heart and action, but a lesson can be learned as well. I rate this film 3 ½ stars.
An outstanding Wes Anderson Film
It was like reuniting with an old friend.
It's Wes Anderson, there's nothing else to say.

Ralph Fiennes is a delight in this fun, eccentric and often hilarious film from Wes Anderson.  
All of the usual players show up in this one as well including Bill Murray, Owen Wilson, Adrien Brody, Willem Dafoe, F Murray Abraham and so many more. 
This tells the story of a concierge and be his trusty lobby boy in a fancy European hotel surrounded by the oncoming war.  This is one of those films that is just a joy to watch.
great pacing, interesting characters and a compelling storyline. All the aspects of a good movie can be found in this wonderful movie about a bellhop and his boss

Wes Anderson es mas que un director, es un artista; el gran hotel de Budapest, es mas que una película, es... arte.  En el gran hotel de Budapest, los denominados "aspectos técnicos" pasan a ser "aspectos artísticos", al ver esta obra maestra nos evoca una pintura, y coincidencialmente, la historia de la película gira en torno a precisamente ese detalle, una pintura, una pintura, que se refleja en aspectos como su inigualable maquillaje, su colorido y simpatizante vestuario, su divertida banda sonora, su fotografía y, sobre todo, su meticuloso, colorido, original y llamativo diseño de producción, que es tan, pero tan elegante que le valió un óscar a mejor escenografía. Anderson crea personajes demasiado excéntricos y por ende simpatizantes, como es el caso del personaje de Ralph Fiennes, cuyo personaje está muy bien construido y es el más simpático y divertido de todos. La película está muy, muy bien escrita y dirigida, la historia es ambiciosa y adornada con ironía, simple, pero capaz. es divertida, ya sea por sus chistes, su estilo, sus personajes o el desarrollo de sus acontecimientos, siempre consigue hacerte sonreír o hasta sacarte una carcajada. El gran hotel de Budapest, es de las mejores películas de todo el siglo XXI, y Wes Anderson, es uno de los directores más característicos, originales y de los pocos que son capaces de llegar a revolucionar una industria entera. 8,3/10.
The Best Wes Anderson.
A quirky oddity that manages to be charming and inexplicably entertaining.

To be honest, I am not the biggest fan of Wes Anderson movies, but The Grand Budapest Hotel is excellent. It's wacky, it's fun, the design is flawless and the acting brilliant. The only real flaw I had with the movie is that I wanted to see more of certain characters, and that in itself is a compliment to how great the movie is. This is satire at its best and well worth the watch.

The overarching story is easy to understand and there are a number of great settings and visual moods which are done quite well but they don't make up for the lack of entertainment from beginning to end of this movie. Overall, while I understand what Wes Anderson was going for, the overall package didn't provide an entertaining experience for me.

Wes Anderson outdoes himself with The Grand Budapest Hotel, a mash up of all the auteur stylings evident in his earlier movies.  There is a vibrant color palette.  There are lengthy tracking shots.  There are plenty of stylish pans and zooms.  There is an all-star cast, including several of Anderson's regulars (Owen Wilson, Jason Schwartzman, Bill Murray). To add to all of this, Anderson also includes some black and white footage and, to mix things up a bit, changes aspect ratios from time to time.  It's the story of M. Gustave (Ralph Fiennes), the concierge at an upscale hotel, and his devoted lobby boy Zero (Tony Revolori), as they elude villains involved in a disputed inheritance and evade police who believe that Gustave has killed his 84 year-old lover.  As would be expected, it's irreverent, visually arresting, and relentlessly entertaining.

There's no doubt The Grand Budapest Hotel is one of Anderson's most ostentatious films to date. The symphony of colours, whimsical story, and witty dialogue are married together seamlessly, heightening his trademark aesthetic. The attention to detail is phenomenal and not a second is wasted on presenting a nearly perfect blend of visual artistry. While its three-layered narratives may seem ambitious, the filmmaker triumphantly finds a balance between friendship, romance, villainous treachery, and politics. Admittedly, one could argue the filmmaker's idiosyncratic direction is style over substance. However, beneath the surface is a melancholic social critique of humanity. Regardless, The Grand Budapest Hotel is almost as sweet as Mendl's confectionary.

Grand Budapest Hotel tells the story of the friendship between a concierge and lobby boy at one of the classiest hotels of the time. The audience is introduced to the subject through an author recalling an interview he had with the lobby boy much later in the lobby boy's life. Although the depth of the narration is a bit confusing and frustrating at first, it pays homage to the fact that it was a real story first recorded in a book then retold as a movie. The plot itself was satisfying. A grand tale with high stakes and a satisfying resolution. But the movie really shines with its characters. The lobby boy impresses with his loyalty. The concierge is a fascinating, funny, and complex man. Ultimately my favorite part of the movie wasn't the story itself but rather how the story was told. The movie does not take itself too seriously. All the characters fill out their roles with exaggeration. The villains, exceedingly dastardly and cruel. The lobby boy, steadfastly loyal, almost the concierge's shadow. The concierge, noble, suave, and kind, the very personification of class. As well the pacing of the characters movement is hurried and purposeful to the extreme, adding a comical effect. Overall a fantastic movie.

No one does a movie like Wes Anderson, known best for his perfectly symmetrical shots and aesthetically pleasing coloring, the 2014 film "The Grand Budapest Hotel" is one of his best works yet. Though he has faced much critique for having less "artistic" films and more "artful" films, I believe these specific choices do not lack distinctive meaning and are brilliantly portrayed in this film.  The story encapsulates two main characters, the ones that stand out the most are M. Gustave, played by Ralph Fiennes, accompanied by his bell boy Zero, played by Tony Revolori a first-time major motion picture actor. Alongside a star-studded cast of Hollywood actors, these two wrap the whimsical world of a glamorous 1930s Hungarian hotel into a short hour and forty minutes. Anderson uses the change of lighting and coloring to shift the focuses and time periods in the piece for example, dimming the lights for dramatic effect when the narrator is telling an important detail and switching to warm bright colors when he is speaking of things like Zero's love interest Agatha. Though a center focus may seem unnatural, Wes Anderson uses it to draw the audience away from the story at times to focus on its beautiful framing, tricking the audience into seeing so much more than just the words spoken in the story. The movie may be so appealing because through this language of framing we are allowed to re-live the feeling of a picture book we enjoyed as a child, when stories were not just words on a page but rather an imaginative escape into the world of the written characters, (which makes sense considering this movie was based on book itself). Overall, if you're looking for witty humor, artistic pictures, and a heartfelt  story, look no further and enjoy the hilarious adventure Wes Anderson paints in the Grand Budapest Hotel.
THE GRAND BUDAPEST HOTEL 8.25

The Grand Budapest Hotel, written by Wes Anderson, is a charming and chaotic tragicomedy that tells the tale of how a man came to own The Grand Budapest Hotel. Anderson is able to demonstrate the importance of grace, honor, and loyalty and most importantly the significance of forging relationships and displaying kindness towards people. Unlike other films within this genre this film has an emphasis on crisp colors and visually pleasing cinematography. Furthermore, it uses over dramatization of situations in order to evoke a comedic effect. Unlike Wes Andersons other work, such as Sing and Fantastic Mr.Fox, this film combines tragedy along with it's comedical writing style. Because of the lighthearted music and bright color scheme, scenes in which there is a violence offer a stark contrast and give a shock to the audience. Using these elements, the writer is able to focus on the importance of upholding and creating relationships with individuals, as well as upholding honor and loyalty. And doing what you can to help a person out. All in all, I would give this film four out of five stars. I immensely enjoyed the mix of comedy and tragedy within the film, and I found the cinematography to be compelling and spectacular. However, I found the film to be entirely too predictable. In addition to this there was little to no character arc throughout the film that was evident, and the social commentary was difficult to understand and find. Nevertheless, the film was fairly effective. The crispness in the colors used helped to create a charming atmosphere, and as I mentioned before I highly enjoyed the stark contrast to the scenes that displayed violence. The plot of the film was fairly chaotic and intriguing, but the overall resolution was predictable. Additionally, the soundtrack and dialogue used was extremely enjoyable. Much like other films within this same genre, the downplaying of violent scenes as well as the over-dramatizing events helped in making the film extremely enjoyable. All in all I would say that this film teaches an important lesson in upholding oneself with dignity and doing what you can for others.

A mani basse il migliore della filmografia di Wes Anderson ed uno dei migliori film del 2014. Il suo stile personale viene elevato all'ennesima potenza e si sposa perfettamente con una narrativa che gli calza a pennello. Tutto è coerente e si intreccia alla perfezione, in un'esperienza raffinata che non nasconde umorismo elegante e della sana volgarità. Non è lo stile registico ad essere innovativo, perché è presente in praticamente tutti i suoi film, ma è proprio il modo in cui si vengono ad unire tutti i vari aspetti tecnici e narrativi per creare un intreccio di assoluta novità. In altre parole, utilizzando i soliti ingredienti, Wes Anderson si inventa una nuova geniale ricetta. Probabilmente, sarà ricordato come il suo capolavoro più riuscito.

In his film, Wes Anderson cleverly plays with whimsical aesthetics reflective of the European Art Nouveau style, which dress the harsh reality of a pseudo-fascist regime that takes place in a fictional Zubrowka. To me, Anderson has blurred the line between the political and fantastical quite well, which allows the audience to reach a deeper understanding of the contextual politics driving the film's plot. Sequences which are borderline comical and provide a value of entertainment such as the chase scene between Gustave and Dmitri, are inter-spliced with more politically charged scenes such as the train scene where we see an altercation between Zero and Gustave with soldiers which resulting in the destruction of Zero's documentation. I think this heightens the degree of consciousness the film has of its own political themes because of how well they're integrated with the fantasy and comedy. At the same time however, Anderson distances his film from portraying true events by setting the story in a time not symbolic of the event it is modelling. For example, we know that Anderson is trying to emulate the Nazi regime, but his story takes place in 1932, way before Hitler came into power. This further drives the mythological position Anderson plays with.
The inter-textual use of art in the film also acts as a mean of balancing the relationship between fantasy and politics. Anderson's featuring of Michael Taylor's painting "Boy With Apple", serves as a McGuffin that facilitates the audience's understanding of each of the characters through the way each of them interacts with the painting. For example, Dmitri's utter rejection of the idea of a concierge owning such a priceless painting showed me that to him the painting was a symbol of wealth and that he ideologically perpetuates a classist perspective, which in itself is political. The fact that the painting is not even real and was painted by Taylor specifically for the film only highlights to me the brilliance of politics and fantasy acting in relation with one another.
Adding to its socio-economic dimensions is Anderson's Art Nouveau stylings I mentioned earlier. By using this type of architecture, which is symbolic of an over-saturation in wealth, the glorification of this class system during this time period is made evident. The glaring difference we see in scenes from 1968 which show a more stripped-down version of the hotel which Zero runs is not only done to show the effects of fascist occupation but to me represents an overcoming of the power dynamic and hierarchy of the class system and a movement towards liberated thought. Seeing that it was Zero's version of the Grand Budapest Hotel only solidified it for me further because of how he was represented as the other (not of high society I mean) in earlier scenes from 1932. While it was a departure from the luxurious establishment it once was it signifies Zero's development from starting as the lobby-boy as well as his immigrant status largely defining him and how he's treated, to eventually becoming the hotel's proprietor, which I believe is a moment of working through the politics that have fought against him.
In terms of the form of the film, Anderson has remained true to his signature style with the way he uses color, composition and camera angles. His first establishing shot is already enticing enough to make you want to continue watching the film, with its pan up towards the remarkable hotel set against a scenery which emulates a painting. This is smart in the way that it sets up the importance of aesthetic. Reminiscent of many of his other films, Anderson's shots are very symmetrical and its clear that he tries to make them look perfect, which is ironic considering how flawed his characters are. I feel like this only adds more to the comedic aspect of the movie. In terms of composition, I like the way Anderson first places Gustave in front of the frame with Zero always behind him, we can tell who holds the power in their relationship. But as the movie progresses, we see a shift in this with Zero slowly being placed in frame directly next to Gustave and we see them become equals. This visual movement is a physical representation of Zero's moment of working through that I mentioned earlier, as he becomes more in tune with his identity.
Anderson is very brilliant in his ability to create a film which is aesthetically pleasing and comedic enough that it draws audiences in, but he then uses this modality of entertainment to explore important socio-economic and political themes while also entertaining his audience. This, I think, makes the film easy to watch even if it deals with darker themes. Wes Anderson films are always very thoughtful and deliberate, and The Grand Budapest Hotel is no exception.

The Grand Budapest Hotel is one of the most Wes Anderson movies out there. His distinct style seems to surprise me in every one of his movies, especially this one. His format shouldn't work, however, it always does. Next to Rushmore, I'd put this as his best work. The movie had a beautiful pallet and overall design. The way Wes Anderson positioned the camera made every shot a piece of art. His way of making a comedy really works here. The acting is superb. I really enjoyed Ralph Fiennes's performance as M. Gustave. I felt that he was able to bring the right amount of comedy to the role that, at times, reminded me of Fawlty Towers. I also liked seeing Tony Revolori in a role other than Flash in Spider-Man, I feel that he did a great job portraying the timid lobby boy. Obviously, Saoirse Ronan is great in this, along with everything else she does. The script in this is fantastic, allowing the characters to stand out from one and other. Another thing I love about this movie is the score. Still, above all, the colors in this movie really make it work, along with the set design. I've found that Wes Anderson's focus in film is making everything look perfect, especially because the character's aren't. This stark contrast is what makes his movies funny. There are obviously some problems with the movie. One of the glaring problems for me is that I felt the tension sometimes didn't work, and I feel that some of the conflict and emotional moments didn't hit as hard as they should have. The comedic characters are great, but I feel that in a way, they were 2 dimensional, which I suppose was part of the movie in a way. Still, this movie was definitely deserving of the best picture nomination it received. Watching all of Wes Anderson's movies in order has made me appreciate the development of his style. Slowly, movie by movie, Wes Anderson begins developing the distinct style he is known for today. I believe that The Grand Budapest Hotel is the best example of his personal style, and that is why it's one of my favorites. 9.4/10

The Grand Budapest Hotel recounts the story of M. Gustave (Ralph Fiennes) and his adventures during a battle for an enormous family fortune. I have been avoiding this movie like the plague because the trailers didn't really grab me. As it turns out, not only is the movie phenomenal, but it quickly became one of my favorites.

Acting: 10
Ralph Fiennes really makes this movie pop as Gustave. His wit is a huge part of his charm and impacts the way he acts out each scene. Characters like his are refreshing and hook you into the movie. I enjoyed Tony Revolori's role as well playing bellhop Zero Moustafa. The two work so well together and enhance the movie as a result.

Beginning: 10
The beginning isn't perfect, but I gave it a perfect score because it's extremely intriguing. By the closing of the first ten minutes, I had a strong feeling I was in for a treat the rest of the way through. I was right.

Characters: 10

Cinematography/Visuals: 10
Director Wes Anderson is known for a specific style that's so different from anything else out there and The Grand Budapest Hotel is no exception. Colors pop and images jump out at you in exactly the way he is trying to convey. His style, hard to explain at times, is hard not to appreciate and enjoy. When you watch a movie like this, you truly feel like you are getting a full-on cinematic experience.

Conflict: 10
There is a scene towards the back half of the movie that I call "The Escape". It is action-packed yet has some subtle nuances at the same time. Definitely one of my favorite scenes in the movie, but not the only one hinging on conflict. Despite a comedic overtone, the film relies on a number of different points of tension to drive the plot.

Entertainment Value: 9

Memorability: 10
Gustave and Zero are easily one of my favorite duos since Jack and Rose in Titanic. They have a strange relationship, one that contributes to making the movie unforgettable. There are so many moments that stand out (the reading of the will comes to mind) making this a movie hard not to think about. It's a movie you can watch a number of times and see something new each time.

Pace: 10

Plot: 10
Flawless storytelling. Magical and original. Enough said.

Resolution: 4

Overall: 93

The Grand Budapest Hotel is a thoroughly fun, eclectic, and entertaining Wes Anderson flick. Wes Anderson truly hones in on his style of film-making (which is basically a genre of its own at this point) and utilizes a brilliant ensemble cast to craft a unique narrative about a fictional hotel during 'World War II.' Ralph Fiennes was simply brilliant and Tony Revolori was a revelation! Their deft interplay was evident from the first moments they shared the screen together. Every moment they shared on screen together was whimsical fun as the two got into quite a few precarious situations. The villains were perfectly cast as Adrien Brody's douchbaggery and Willem Defoe's terrifying mug made for completely reprehensible but thoroughly entertaining heels for the film. Cameo appearances were also aplenty, with Saoirse Ronan and Bill Murray stealing scene after scene. The set design was gorgeous and fantastical, with no detail left untouched. I will definitely have to watch the film again and again to catch all the little fun touches. The humor worked perfectly and complimented the outlandish plot, similar to the Coen Brothers in 'O Brother, Where Art Thou.' The prison scenes were especially entertaining as the resourcefulness of the characters made for a thoroughly entertaining sequence for an equally entertaining (and quite frankly, ridiculous) escape. The whole film felt at the same time serious and emotional and completely tongue-in-cheek. That is the true mark of a Wes Anderson flick and I am thoroughly excited to see what The French Dispatch has to offer. Overall, this is a must watch for any fans of Wes Anderson and of film in general and is a great way to immerse oneself in Anderson's eclectic filmography.

I shall have to watch it again at some point. I feel it might change. As it would. Or it should, thanks to the 'unreliable narrators'

Wes Anderson's indie absurdist comedy-drama The Grand Budapest Hotel (2014) is absolute nonsensical comedy and pure joy filmmaking for 100 minutes of delightful charm. Wes Anderson's direction is sublime and fast in one of his funniest features. The odd humor and resonant dramatic moments keep you guessing as he lures you in with elegant charm and stays engaged because of all the quirky characters and sleek filmmaking. Wes Anderson and Hugo Guinness adapt Stefan Zweig's novels into a surreal crime mystery full of endless absurdist humor of the highest caliber. You will not stop smiling during The Grand Budapest Hotel until the credit hit.

All the delicate pinks and vibrant purples in Stephan O. Gessler and Adam Stockhausen's production design make The Grand Budapest Hotel look like a luxurious period dollhouse. It's so beautiful to look at Robert Yeoman's cinematography as every shot is a cute square and close medium shot of adorable perfection. His style is so refreshing and breathtaking that it's clearly influenced anyone from Paul King's Paddington and Paddington 2 to Rian Johnson's Knives Out. Barney Pilling's editing is quick with slick cuts from one decorative German locale to another lavish spot. Milena Canonero's costumes are neat concierge uniforms to period soldier uniforms all in striking purple or black. She outdid herself with these outfits of colorful flair.

Alexandre Desplat's score is so pleasant as his whimsical charm is still present in his ambient sounds that are more electronic this time around, yet remain graceful. His movie music is refined, yet chaotic fun and always fun to hear. Heike Merker and Norma Webb's make-up is excellent as they age Tilda Swinton decades into an elderly lady, in a role that she delivers convincingly. Meanwhile, they give all the gentlemen of The Grand Budapest Hotel an air of sophistication and grace. All the ladies are gifted with cute looks and restrained beauty with pulled back hair and neat dresses.

I must mention Ralph Fiennes elevates The Grand Budapest Hotel into all time great comedy status thanks to his riveting and hilarious comedic turn as Monsieur Gustave H. His endless poetic ramblings and rude offhand remarks are just too funny. Tony Revolori is fun as the steadfast lobby boy Young Zero Moustafa. F. Murray Abraham is heartbreaking and interesting as Old Zero Moustafa. Jude Law is excellent as the Young Writer, who is our narrator along with Tom Wilkinson as the Old Author.

I loved Mathieu Amalric as the secretive Serge X. Adrien Brody steals every scene he's in as the scoundrel heir Dmitri Desgoffe-und-Taxis. His sudden curses and calm walk show a level of refinement to his acting that allows him to be intimidating without trying too hard. Willem Dafoe is monstrous as the serial killer J.G. Jopling. Jeff Goldblum is funny as the lawyer Deputy Vilmos Kovacs. His cat getting killed is so funny like how Wes Anderson kills off many of his furry creatures suddenly in his features.

Saoirse Ronan is magical and sympathetic as the pastry girl Agatha. She's captivating every second she is on screen. I simply adore Léa Seydoux, so it is delightful seeing her as the maid Clotilde. My only complaint to Wes Anderson is that Ronan and Seydoux should have had more lines!

Harvey Keitel is cool and funny as the tough prisoner Ludwig. Bill Murray gets a fun cameo as Monsieur Ivan, meanwhile, Jason Schwartzman is funny as the lazy Monsieur Jean. I really enjoyed seeing Owen Wilson in a Wes Andreson feature again as the helpful Monsieur Chuck. Edward Norton cameos as a pivotal character called Inspector Albert Henckels. Furthermore, Wes Anderson puts in all manner of cameos of actors from his previous films for the astute fan of his extensive filmography now.

In all, Wes Anderson utilizes his magnificent cast wonderfully resulting in an enchanting picture.

Wes Anderson is one of the few directors whose films can immediately be identified as having been directed by him due to their distinct visual style, cutesy dialogue and the actors he frequently collaborates with. This is one of his most popular films as it is an exquisitely crafted picture of unique delights that revels in one beautifully framed shot after another. Fans of Anderson's are sure to be delighted, I count myself among them, but even those who are not completely entranced will find a surprising amount of depth in the central relationship portrayed in this film. The film is deserving of the critical acclaim it received and was one of the best films nominated for Best Picture in 2014 in an otherwise lackluster lineup.

M. Gustave, Ralph Fiennes, runs the Grand Budapest Hotel in 1932 while carrying on affairs with a variety of older, high maintenance women. Chief among them is Celine Villeneuve Desgoffe und Taxis, Tilda Swinton, who leaves him the priceless "Boy with Apple" painting after she dies much to the consternation of her selfish son Dmitri, Adrien Brody, who hires assassin J.G. Jopling, Willem Dafoe, to track him down. Meanwhile Gustave has taken bellhop Zero, Tony Revolori, under his wing and the two go on the run together as Zero begins a romance with baker Agatha, Saoirse Ronan, and their country goes through political turmoil. They are able to successfully evade their captors for a long time through various complex schemes but eventually a shootout occurs in the hotel that leads to further revelations about the will of Villeneuve Desgoffe und Taxis.

The whole film begins about three different framing devices which sets up immediately that the film is more focused on stylistic flourishes and appearances than a plot. Beauty is a major focus of the film as it is wonderful to have Anderson step you through the various details of how a pastry containing contraband tools was constructed. We also get to learn all of the intricacies of the lives of the people inhabiting the film as while they are big and cartoonish you do come to care as much as they do about living life in a way that is proper. Gustave's commitment to wearing a specific perfume, enunciating all of his words perfectly and appreciating the loyalty of his friend is honorable in a way and the Nazi-like figures looming in the background only make his ideals appear more admirable.

Fiennes also gives one of his greatest performances as in a rare comedic role he proves that he can blend his posh, uptight persona with a dash of wit and comes out giving one of the most entertaining characterizations of the year. His ability to rattle off impossibly long lines of dialogue is unmatched and you can almost smell the oft-spoken about perfume his character is said to wear as his character goes about his business in this film. The supporting cast also get moments to shine, as you would expect from a group of performers so highly distinguished, because while there is not the depth of the characters found in Rushmore (1998) and The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004) there is still entertainment to be had in these broad characterizations. Brody gives a typically high spirited performance as the chief villain and Dafoe brings a quiet menace to the role of the ruthless hitman. Ronan gets less to do and cameos from Owen Wilson and Bill Murray feel perfunctory but at least for the audience there is a moment of excitement at spotting actors who have played significant roles in Anderson's other films.

Finally, the extraordinary beauty of the film must be discussed as several shots of spectacularly framed interiors in which every detail has clearly been pored over for hours make you sit back in awe. The costumes, the interiors, the production design and even the fictional ‘famous' painting are top notch and the efforts of Anderson are obvious as the visuals are reminiscent of his previous work. Those who worked on the production must have faced hours of painstaking work but their efforts were absolutely worth it because the end product appears flawless. Anderson is a master of style and if that's something that you value in your entertainment this is a visual feast.

Wes Anderson is perhaps one of the most delightfully unusual filmmakers working today, his films characterised by picturesque symmetry, wry humour and more than a hint of the macabre. The Grand Budapest Hotel is no different and actually stands as one of Anderson's finest films; it's precisely choreographed, gorgeous to look at and, above all, an intelligent comedy that pays homage to bygone cinema whilst adding its own unique spin.
Though the action may jump time periods (whether it's from Tom Wilkinson's direct narrator or F. Murray Abraham's narrator within the story), it centres around The Grand Budapest Hotel, an elite establishment for the rich and pampered in the fictional state of Zubrowka. Our attention is immediately turned to M. Gustave (Ralph Fiennes), the hotel's concierge, who tends to the guests with a managed slickness... that is when he isn't courting dowagers into his room. The film takes off on a race of storytelling, as Gustave is framed for the murder of an old lover (a prosthetic-clad Tilda Swinton) and must flee the law and who knows else with only the help of his protege, lobby boy, Zero (a suitably boyish Tony Revelori, when not played 30 years down the line by a mellow F. Murray Abraham).
The film is a delightful farce, Anderson and Hugo Guiness' script providing intelligent and subtle comedy that delivers even amid such a frenetic and occasionally scatty pace. For the most part though, The Grand Budapest Hotel is as tightly wound as one could expect from Wes Anderson; even amid the absurdity of ski chases and severed fingers, there's a remarkable level of control to the madness, helped along by Anderson's assured writing and direction. 
Employed in the cast is a who's who of star-studded spectacle; Ralph Fiennes, Willem Dafoe and Saoirse Ronan are plot-central, but around them are bit cameos from the likes of Bill Murray, Jeff Goldblum and Lea Seydoux. Fiennes leads with rapier-sharp timing as Gustave, his performance radiating clipped composure, all complete with an irresistible charm. The supporting cast are admittedly largely one-note (occasionally the abundance of celebrity proves a little distracting) but are earnest enough to drive the film through.
Where the film has perhaps received the highest praise, however, is its design. The Grand Budapest hotel is a visual treat, its design vibrant yet avowedly architected. There's almost a sense of the characters having been painted on screen; from the bright colours, sharp angles and miniature set pieces, the film feels as much a spectacle of art as an espionage romp. Alexandre Desplat's score is perfectly judged, the musical voice established by the distinct and innovative use of the balalaika. The film is shot with equal verve, snapping from camera ratios incessantly to produce an energised and unexpected cinematography that boosts the narrative. At points, the movie may be a case of style over substance, but the film's unusual design only seems to enhance one's enjoyment of it.

SCOTT: (Dr. Scott Allison, Professor of Psychology, University of Richmond) Greg, are you Hungary to review The Grand Budapest Hotel?

GREG: (Greg Smith, Founder of Agile Writers of Richmond, VA) You keep pestering me to do it, so let s recap!

SCOTT: The movie begins with a young girl admiring a statue of a man simply known as  The Author.  She begins reading one of his books that describes a trip he made in 1968 to the Grand Budapest Hotel. At that time the drab, outdated hotel attracted very few customers. During his stay, the Author (Jude Law) encounters the owner, Zero Moustafa (F. Murray Abraham), who is anxious to tell his story of how he came to own the Grand Budapest.

GREG: That causes another flashback to 1932 where a young Zero is taken under the wing of concierge extraordinaire M. Gustave (Ralph Fiennes). Gustave is quite the lady s man - if by lady you mean elderly widow. One of his  friends  has died and left him a fortune in the form of a priceless painting Boy with Apple. However, the children of the deceased are not willing to let the painting go that easily. They frame Gustave and he escapes from prison. Now the chase is on as Gustave and Zero are on a mission to clear his name and recover the painting.

SCOTT: Greg, The Grand Budapest Hotel is a strange movie about strange people. The movie tells the story of a man, Gustave, who is overly polite and loquacious in situations that call for neither quality. Gustave is a mentor figure for a young lobby boy named Zero who appears incapable of showing any facial expressions. The duo get caught up in a dangerous plot with many other equally strange people, each of whom has some quirky or menacing mannerism. Wes Anderson-world is stylistically surreal and cartoon-like. Pastel colors tend to dominate and actors are instructed to master the art of nonverbal minimalism with their bodies, faces, and movements. There seems to be an exaggerated attempt to create and nurture caricatures of people and situations. Sometimes the effect is comical; at other times it is merely odd. If the goal was to make the movie sets and characters memorable, in a way that a bottle of Pepto-Bismol is memorable, then the goal has been achieved.

GREG: I enjoyed Budapest very much. Wes Anderson always delivers an experience that you won t find in other films. Last year s Moonlight Kingdom was another standout movie by Anderson. The characters are always likable and innocent in their own way. If I have a complaint about Budapest it is that it dragged on in the second act. The film clocks in at just 100 minutes, but it felt like much longer. Another complaint was the appearance of too many cameos. There is a hotel shootout that had so many luminaries pop into frame that I was distracted from the story.

SCOTT: Ironically, within a movie that is as unconventional as a movie can get, we have a rather conventional hero-sidekick combination. This is not to say that these dual heroes are uninteresting. Far from it, in fact. Gustave does a fair amount of mentoring of Zero, who grows from a youthful innocent boy into an informed and experienced young man. Gustave relishes his role as a mentor to Zero, and while I m not sure that Gustave changes much during the course of the movie, he certainly has plenty of heroic traits. In fact, he dies performing an act of self-sacrifice.

GREG: I agree, Scott. In our book on heroes in the movies Reel Heroes: Volume 1 we lay out the Hero/Sidekick as one of the types of duo-heroes. Gustave and Zero play this pattern to full force. Zero knows nothing of the world of hotels yet Gustave feels sorry for the boy because he is a refugee. Here, the hero is the mentor to the young man whom we care about because of his innocence and underdog status. The story if rife with villains as well. We meet the eldest son of the widow, Dmitri (Adrien Brody) who is intent on having the painting for his own. I was pleased with the coloring of Dmitri. He is a vile man and we get a bit of his backstory as the scorned son of Madame D. Dmitri enlists the aid of a diabolical and evil henchman named Jopling (Willem Dafoe) who has steel teeth and wears rings that double as brass knuckles. While we don t get a lot of backstory on Jopling, he demonstrates his villainy with the many killings and maiming of characters in the story.

SCOTT: The two main villains are a detestable pair for different reasons - Dmitri for his loathsome greed and Jopling for his psychopathic brutality. The movie doesn t delve into the details of these two villains  histories or life stories. These bad guys exist mainly to provide a grave challenge to Gustave and Zero. It s interesting how movies often pack their villains with a familiar one-two punch. The main villain is often the mastermind of the operation, and the secondary villain(s) are usually the muscle who carry out the physical dirty work. This split-structure of villainy represents a departure from the more unified structure of the hero, who in order to succeed must possess both brains and brawn.

GREG: Scott, I enjoyed myself at The Grand Budapest Hotel and could find myself going back for a second visit. The characters were colorful and unique. While it was a bit slow in places, the film held my interest for most of the time. I give Budapest 4 out of 5 Reels. The heroes in this story were likable, even affable. I enjoyed watching M. Gustave s growing fondness for Zero and Zero s growth under Gustave s tutelage. I give the hero-pair 4 out of 5 Heroes. The villains were more complete in this film compared to others we ve reviewed so far this year. However that isn t saying much. Still, they were stereotypes of villains gone by as the estranged son and his henchman. I give these evil-doers just 3 out of 5 Villains. Movie: Heroes:  Villains: 

SCOTT: The Grand Budapest Hotel isn t a great movie but it has an endearing and quirky charm that gives it lasting appeal. I give Wes Anderson lots of credit here. After all,  strange  doesn t always mean memorable, but here it does because of Gustave s unique combination of charm, courage, and quirkiness, and also because the film tosses out a look and feel that I ve never seen before. Like you, I ll award The Grand Budapest Hotel 4 Reels out of 5. As I ve mentioned the hero duo of Gustave and Zero doesn t break much new ground, but I have to admire the transformation of Zero, who learns many life lessons from Gustave, not the least of which is loyalty. This is the trait that inspires Zero to hang onto the hotel decades after any rational person might do so. This hero pair earns a solid 3 Heroes out of 5. In keeping with the rest of the movie, the villains were an odd pair that movie audiences love to hate. This mastermind-muscle pairing was effective although their characters were not as developed as they could have been. For the same reasons as you, Greg, I give them 3 Villains out of 5. For his latest feature, Wes Anderson pushes his quirky vision to what may be a new high for him. He combines the multitude of different filming techniques he's become so well-known for, both old and new (symmetrical cinematography, stop-motion/miniatures, etc.), into what is truly his most technically impressive film to date. The key to The Grand Budapest Hotel (no pun intended) that it gets right where his previous film struggled is making sure there's a story worth telling with this technical prowess as a backdrop. Pulling a complete one-eighty from the often cold tale of childhood love in Moonrise Kingdom, this time around Anderson has crafted a zany story-within-a-story murder mystery that is perhaps his funniest film to date. Anderson, of course, has always been a master of dry black humor, but much of the reason this film is so unflinchingly hilarious is the cast he's gathered to tell his story. The ensemble consists of too many names to list but all of whom are predictably great (most of whom are frequent Anderson collaborators), but the two standouts are brand new to being in front of an Anderson-operated camera: that is, Ralph Fiennes and newcomer Tony Revolori. Fiennes' dry wit and comedic timing is impeccable for an actor whose work has been primarily rooted in serious drama, and Revolori perfectly captures the awkwardness that feels like a cinematic extension of Anderson himself. It's easy to go on and on about how comedically perfect of a film this is, and ignoring the fact that Anderson never sacrifices emotion for a laugh. At the undercurrent of all the wackiness is a genuine feeling of romanticism and loss: the fact that Anderson can balance such opposing themes really is a testament to his capabilities as a storyteller, and in that regard, it's certainly not a stretch to call this his magnum opus.

The frantic pace of Wes Anderson's films tends to not sit so well with me - but the artistic direction and witty dialogue of The Grand Budapest Hotel won me over. There is a great attention to detail that brings this world to life and some great bits of dark comedy.

This movie is like that friend that we all have who answers a really simple question by telling you a ridiculous backstory that takes about an hour and a half to get through. Luckily the ridiculous backstory that was told in The Grand Budapest Hotel was entertaining as hell! I have never seen a movie like this in my life. This film was a thriller, comedy, drama, mystery, and romance all packed into 100 minutes. I loved nearly every second of this film, and I would highly recommend it!
Couldn't make it through to the end. I just don't like movies by Wes Anderson. Nothing makes sense to me. Everyone is like a cartoon and not a real person.

Wes Anderson hits it out of the park with his strong, gutsy adherance to a stylish artistic vision. The cinematography is extraordinary, using space and movement very well; the sets clean and appropriately atmospheric; the music tying the movie down to its label of Comedy. With a charming script and a lovely cast, 'The Grand Budapest Hotel' may not be a belly-roarer, but it provides smiles and an odd feeling of warm butterflies.
Few things are more charismatic than this film, the performances were unforgettable as the joy watching it.

'The Grand Budapest Hotel' is heavily packed with a talented cast and stylish visuals but doesn't suffocate under its own weight thanks to a narrative that's deeply emotional.

'The Grand Budapest Hotel' is wildly fun and comical despite it being a murder mystery film. The film takes you on a chase involving a priceless Renaissance painting and a battle for an enormous family fortune, recounting the adventures of Gustave H and Zero Moustafa. Ironically, much of the film's action and plot are staged outside the hotel, which Anderson could've explored more seeing as it was revered to be 'grand' throughout the film after all. A worthy note would be the world Wes Anderson has created once again, The Grand Budapest Hotel and the fictional providence of Zubrowka is warm and vibrant, set against the backdrop of a changing continent soon to enter a war.  

The pairing of Fiennes and Revolori as the lead characters are surprising and delightful despite being new faces to Anderson's films. While much of the supporting characters are Anderson staples such as Adrien Brody, Willem Dafoe Edward Norton, and Bill Murray. The pair truly capture the bond of Gustave H and Zero, the characters' relationship and its development is heart-warming and bittersweet while the dramatization capture the whimsical signature of Anderson. Anderson is quite skilled in crafting adolescent and juvenile characters that we've seen in 'Rushmore,' 'The Royal Tenenbaums,' and 'Moonrise Kingdom,' but his recent take on grown-up characters is still improving.

'The Grand Budapest Hotel' features Wes Anderson essentials-a beautiful and vibrant production design, quirky and eccentric characters, romantic subplot, a warm filter, and a deceptive visual style- that leaves almost nothing to complain about and much to adore.

One of the most enchanting and atmospheric movies I've seen in a long while. Wes Andersons motifs and stylistic marks gel perfectly with the story. Good acting all round but especially from Ralph Fiennes and Tony Revolori. My favourite Wes Anderson film so far.

In true Wes Anderson fashion, The Grand Budapest Hotel is a odd film with plenty of unexpected twists and turns that leave you laughing at the pure delight and absurdity of it all. I wasn't sure what to expect going into this film, but the visuals of this film give almost an other-wordly feel to the atmosphere, and the dialogue is quick-witted and incredibly entertaining. I could see myself returning to this film again a couple times, but it's not on my Top 100 List or anything.

The Bottom Line:
Entertaining, eccentric and unique, this film will give you exactly what you expect in a Wes Anderson film. If you're in the mood for some guffaws and a film that is artistic in it's atmospheric styles, that is what it provides in it's own modest, humble, insignificant...oh, fuck it.

This is certainly his most mature film to date while still maintaining his signature whimsical touch, this above all is a self -aware work. Underlying is a theme that addresses issues of prejuidice and challenges of authority.  M.Gustave may command his picturesque hotel but there is the question of whether or not he receives the same respect outside of this microcasmic setting. In a way, Wes Anderson seems to studying his own concept of world building by taking this macrocasmic perspective on how people view him and reflecting it within the story. Gustave is a symbol of heightened idealism and presentation in a world where this is not always taken as being realistic.
one of the most beautifully shot films of all time, cements a legacy for wes anderson. he's made great films before, and this is by far the greatest.

Splendid comedy about two employees at a luxurious hotel: a "legendary" concierge, and his trusted associate, an insecure lobby boy. Finely tuned, ingeniously funny, and visually dazzling. Fienne's is perfectly cast, in hilarious role as manager. Engaging all the way, and never indulgent, like most of Wes Anderson's work. Scripted by Anderson from an original story by Anderson and Hugo Guinness. Extravagantly produced and fabulously photographed by Robert D. Yeoman.

It takes skill to generate drama from the comedy of the absurd but no one has perfected this art quite like Wes Anderson. This is perhaps his most complete work, packed with an eclectic mix of characters brought marvelously to life by a quite outstanding cast. Everything is larger than life and yet true to life and that is the genius of Anderson's story. A must see.

The grand Budapest hotel is a funny comedy and an all round good movie with an interesting plot. This movie features a brilliant ensemble cast that includes great chemistry between Ralph Fiennes and Tony Revolori and some great natural comedic talent is displayed from Ralph Fiennes. There is a lot of time hops and narrators though which can make the film choppy.
Great filming, interesting plot!

This is a very funny movie. Wes Anderson is really good at making these very different films that people are just captured by. This movie just proves that his talent is really unlimited. Ralph Fiennes is brilliant in this movie, but then again he always is. Then again, his performance in this movie really brought his career to a new point, because he really is a dramatic actor as seen in movies like "Schindler's List" and "The English Patient." The fact that he can do a performance like this, which is basically a comedic performance, is just once again proving why he is one of the greatest actors in Hollywood. He has beautiful chemistry with the young Tony Revolori who is also very good in this movie.

I'm not a huge Wes Anderson fan admittedly. His works tend to be ridiculous snarky character fapfests. The chance to see "Grand Budapest" came my way, and I had big reservations about it. 
I should interrupt and say I'm a big hotel movie fan. The Shining, Barton  Fink, anything that does have a hotel, the older the better, I'm a mark for. This movie has that in spades, the majesticness, and the pretentiousness, this hotel has it. The type of hotel that has hallways and balconies and whatever for god knows what reason, But Anderson  knows, and that's a big plus to this movie. The characters here are funny, and Anderson seemed to tap into the works of Guy Maddin with many of the shots here. Such a joy to watch, and would watch this again in a heartbeat.

this film, more so than Wes Anderson's previous work (besides perhaps Fantastic Mr. Fox), is a very interesting piece of cinema: it's an example of a director testing himself and working within his means to reach out of his comfort zone. this is Anderson's murder-mystery that so well pays homage to detective serials, prison break films, and even films like Clue in it's mission to keep you entertained every step of the way. the production design of his films get better and better and in no way is Grand Budapest an exception - the marriage of three different time periods exceeds in telling the story within a story within a story (within a story?) excellently and uses setting to further the plot and characterization better than even Life Aquatic. the editing was so perfect as well, twists come truly as surprises and the cast reveals itself throughout in a charming and hilarious fashion. don't miss this one.

92% of critics raved about this, and 86% of the general public adored it - That's how I know that I am unique. This film was horrible!  It had probably the most star studded line up I have ever seen with several cameo appearances, none of which improved what was a truly awful and disjointed story. I think, and I mean think, that it was a tale about how an old man came into possession of the Grand Budapest hotel, which was through an odd character named Gustave. Both he and Zero (the now owner) formed a tight working bond that led them to be close friends as well as employer and employee, with Gustave promising to bequeath his newly acclaimed fortune providing Zero stuck by him. He naturally needed Zero's help as he himself was a conman that used women as a means of securing wealth, and the hotel was just a little something he gained using his cunning charm and guile. Throughout the film, Zero is merely an accomplice to Gustave's criminal mind, but is undoubtedly a man of his word, if not somewhat of a freak. They spend the majority of their time fleeing angry relatives of the deceased woman he recently took advantage of, who have hired hitmen to hunt him down. Despite the fingers being point at Gustave for what looks like an intentional murder, spurred on by the lure of the ensuing will, we never really learn the true nature of her death and as is the case for the vast majority of scenes, there are a lot of questions unanswered, and many actions misunderstood. I simply didn't get this, didn't find it entertaining, and its success is beyond me. Clearly the A-list of celebrities deployed must have gone some way to gaining this an A-star status because the content is nothing short of woeful. If I were to see this in a cinema, I would have soon used the opportunity of the dark room for a little shut eye. Maybe this will grow on me when my maturity levels in films increases, but for now it's a very negative recommendation I'm afraid.
