Wes Anderson presents his latest film the Grand Budapest Hotel. In this film a wealthy man tells the tale of how he came to acquire and own once wealthy and illustrious hotel in a fictional country in Europe. The tale mainly involves the former owner of the hotel Gustave H (Ralph Fiennes and how he came to acquire it. What starts a light comedy, the tale unfolds into chases, prison escapes and murder. The Grand Budapest Hotel featured an excellent cast, great narrative and is one of Wes Anderson's best films yet.

Wes Anderson is brilliantly creative in this film that could not be dreamed up by anybody else.  Amazingly fast paced and scenes that could be boring if they weren't so visually engaging and entertaining.  Gorgeously elaborate and grand sets that are offset with mostly goof and the rare quick scary moments.  It shouldn't work, but it's all tied together by the sweet relationship between a morally questionable concierge and his wide-eyed mentee.  Great characters all around, and a fantastic movie.
Wonderful film, almost cried at the end, so much fun.

Wes Andersons latest is a story about a titular hotel and its weird characters in the chase for a missing painting. Anderson definitely has upped the weird factor from his earlier films and that means some propably find it too weird for their taste. I quite enjoyed it although any more weirder would have been too much. Fiennes is perfect as the legendary concierge and the many cameos work. Visually experimental and quirky as a whole this is a must for Anderson fans and open minded viewers as well.
mustafas , sassafras , estaba bacan el diseño
Intriging story that lures you deeper as it builds to the finale! Jenny liked it more than me :)

I've seen every Wes Anderson film and I've yet to connect with a single one.  He has a unique style which he accomplishes expertly, but the substance is always lacking for me.  His characters always feel more like caricatures, either limited in dimensionality or distanced emotionally from the viewer by the director's heavy-handed focus on his aforementioned style.
fascinating and funny story, very entertaining :)

Wes Anderson's signature style flourishes in "The Grand Budapest Hotel."  That is a polite and complimentary way of saying "This movie is very odd."  The ensemble cast alone is reason to watch (since everybody is bound to have a favorite on the list), but the way that each actor is utilized makes it even better.  The list includes Ralph Fiennes, F. Murray Abraham, Willem Dafoe, Adrien Brody, Edward Norton, Saoirse Ronan, Tilda Swinton, and Bill Murray, and that's less than half of the list!  From F. Murray's sophistication to Willem Dafoe's cold-blooded intensity, you never know what type of character the next star will play.  My only complaint about the film is that I wish I could spend more time with each character.  The Russian Matryoshka Doll introduction of the story that quickly transports us from the present to 1985 to 1968 to 1932 seems a bit unnecessary but sets the tone for the entire film.  Anderson's lighthearted approach to serious situations like death, prison, and war make for a viewing experience that I can only describe as "awkwardly enjoyable."  It is amazing how much actually happens in the 100-minute runtime as characters fly in for a short chapter and then disappear for the rest.  I believe that this film will see some Oscar nominations, particularly for its screenplay and acting.  I wouldn't consider it to be one of the best films that I've seen, but the unique style makes me anxious to revisit "The Grand Budapest Hotel" soon.
Only the 2nd of his films that I thought tolerable Fantastic Mr. Fox is the only one that I've actually liked.
Najbolji Andersonov film.

Charming, with terrific characters and performances. I love the stylistic touch of changing the aspect ratio as the story goes back in time. My big question is how does Wes Anderson get his actors to *move* like that? I still think Moonrise Kingdom is the (slightly) better movie, (a few too many deaths at the end for something that feels so whimsical - a nod to the source material, is my guess), but DJ actually likes this one better (because if she could, she'd live in that time).
A Heroic Saga comprising of adventures from the Great Gustave who tries to prove his innocence using his finesse.The story was set in the War backdrop and got great comedy.

12/29/14 This film is very quirky film.  It is mildly humorous, but some of the strange little gags can be pretty funny, if only because it makes you wonder what just happened.  The sets are interesting in their un-authenticness. Overall, strange, but interesting to watch because it keeps you wondering what strange thing is going to happen next.

Saw the 2014 critically-acclaimed Grand Budapest Hotel that was only in limited release opening season. This was my first-ever approach to Wes Anderson's movies, so my perspective is wholly unique and somewhat virginal. I had my ACOG sight clipped on, my eyes were locked in. And, notably, I liked his style, especially his specificity. Everything is exactly how Anderson wants it to be. He has both the smaller and bigger pictures in his mind that he pencils in masterfully. There was broad and narrow themes and Wes portrays them so accurately and so precisely. I believe the parody of Anderson is the symmetrical composed shots, and this movie really takes that at its word and encompasses that. I mean every single shot is of that style. The aspect ratios of the screen even change through the different timeline brackets, which was cool, including the crisp black and white scene at the end. The camera feels on train tracks or on a rotator cuff at times. Ralph Fiennes is spectacular in this movie. He is so nuance. You think he is this sort of English dandy, prim and proper, but then it breaks away at the seams with these fits of cussing and moments of cruelty mixed with beauty. He is just such an interesting character. There is a story within a story within a story within a story. The storylines are layered like a Mendl's cake. And storytelling ends up being what the movie is ultimately about, I think. The idea that when a story gets filtered through different people. Different interpretations get driven through it and heighten it and deepen it in certain spots. It's probably lost consistency over the tellings and retellings of the story. I found myself breathing in the sweet aroma of this movie and was left completely breathless at the end. Wes Anderson is spinning this yarn with these characters. And I was delightfully following the thread the whole way through. I realize it's hard to walk the line of a drama comedy, yet they balance the tone at emotional equilibrium. I mean, both the funniness and the grave seriousness, Ralph Fiennes and Anthony Quinonez (had to spell-check that) pull it off with such panache. Wink. Quick word on Zero. I love the vintage morale of Zero's devotion to his job and how that's intwined with his identity and character. That resonated with me because I mourn the loss of that in places of businesses today. I far too often go to those places and have people giving off this err of not giving a dang. And I love the message relayed by Zero being emotionally invested in his job. One other thing: Ed Norton, by all accounts should be speaking in a German accent right? And that guy at the end who looked like Father Abraham. We're expected to believe that was Zero 50 years later. He's not even the same race. That being said, I think with Wes Anderson, he's stooped in his own rebellious schemes, that he's willing to break Hollywood rules and confidently construct his own universe. Also, best hotel movie I've seen to date, I think.
THIS is the type of movie that would never normally register on my Radar, Genre wise! And without a doubt one of the most entertaining films I've seen in years!!
Well directed and crafted, The Grand Budapest hotel is breezily entertaining, but Wes Anderson's wild and surreal style will not please all viewers.

If you're a big Wes Anderson fan (Rushmore, The Royal Tenenbaums, Darjeeling Limited, The Life Aquatic, etc.), then you'll probably love this one too.  It's beautifully photographed and filled to the brim with an all-star cast of notable actors and actresses.

The Grand Budapest Hotel is about the misadventures of the hotel's concierge, Gustave H. (Ralph Fiennes) and the lobby boy, Zero Moustafa (Tony Revolori) who follows him around.
The first ten minutes are incredibly slow, but the rest of the film is everything you'd expect from a Wes Anderson movie. The cast is great and the visuals have never been better,
Película muy diferente, cómica en su forma particular, donde la nostalgia es el corazón de la historia.

"Are you Monsieur Gustave of the Grand Budapest Hotel in Nebelsbad?" To watch Ralph Fiennes as Monsieur Gustave of the Brand Budapest Hotel go through this question and answer dance several times is one of the many delights Wes Anderson has packed into his latest film. As we follow Zero Moustafa (played by F Murray Abraham) recount his stories of his days as a young lobby boy and his adventures with M. Gustave, the womanizing manager of the hotel. I honestly have never seen Wes Anderson at his worse, but I feel like this is Wes Anderson at his best. From the cinematography, the color to the quirkiness of the dialogue. Oh, the film is funny as hell! It's no wonder that everyone from Ralph Fiennes to Bill Murray wants to be in his film. Wes Anderson is absolutely one of the most creative minds making movies today. This could be my favorite film of the year. So says the Geek. Five Ball Point Pens.

Whenever I read reviews of Wes Anderson movies they usually reference how audiences either love or hate his works. I can't imagine this movie will change that trend but, if like me, you love Wes Anderson movies this will be a real treat.
The storytelling is layered through narrators at varying stages of their lives with the Grand Budapest as, both the fulcrum of the narrative, and a character all in its own right. Shots are framed and colours pop from every frame with each scene meticulously composed for the viewer to absorb the characters and story on every level.
Anderson reminds us of the pure escapism of cinema at its finest while showcasing characters that, given lesser collective talent, may have seemed farcical. Luckily for us they are just delightfully eccentric. Enjoy.

My personal film of the year (yet to see Under the Skin mind you). Slapstick and wonderfully stylish. Ralph Fines is sensational as the concierge and should get an Oscar nod but my favorite is Willem DeFoe's over the top performance as the henchman Jopling. A feast for the eyes (and ears).

Wes Andersons best work. Visually stunning and an All Star cast contribute to a unique and dynamic storyline. Maybe one of his more serious pictures, it didn't make me laugh as much as Rushmore or The Life Aquatic but I still enjoyed this one the most out of all of his films. I plan on watching this numerous times over the coming months.

The old fashioned theme of The Grand Budapest Hotel is one of the aspects I totally love. It's also smooth, excellent and the cinematography might be one of the best and most unique I have seen. The soundtrack is no exception; it gives the film feeling and pace. 2014 have been a great year, and that totally includes this movie. This film surpassed my expectations; it's almost a flawless film. The directing is spectacular, just as the structure. It's a real adventure, which is both entertaining and cheerful. The characters are great, and I really felt close to them all. There are many well-known actors in The Grand Budapest Hotel, and I really enjoyed that. But Tony Revolori as zero isn't the best actor; he's a bit too stiff for the role.

Wes Anderson's style takes a lot of getting used to. The juxtaposition of vulgarity with civility is not an easy one to manage, but his style tricks an elitist into thinking he or she is watching something artistic, when in fact, it's something quite profane. It's basically Mel Brooks for the NPR/Trader Joe's crowd. This movie is all style and little substance, with elementary characters that have the depth of a Saturday morning cartoon. When you realize that's what you're watching, Wes Anderson seems a lot less pretentious and more fun. I wish the same could be said about the fans of his work.
Engaging narrative, great cast, Anderson cinematography. Very good.

Há uma série de aspectos positivos que devem ser assinalados em "The Grand Budapest Hotel": em primeiro lugar talvez a enorme facilidade com que consegue ser superior ao quase embaraçoso "Moonrise Kindgom" (do qual hoje recordo um puto com óculos e pouco mais). Nesta "comédia de heranças", filmada com uma peculiar noção de screwball e a extravagância habitual do realizador, Wes Anderson consegue pelo menos ser muito mais objectivo na história que quer contar. E a verdade é que pega nessa mesma história com um irresistível ritmo de 400 metros crawl, que não ficaria para trás se tivesse de nadar ao lado do Scorsese mais acelerado ("Goodfellas", "The Wolf of Wall Street"). Tendo isso em conta e entretidos também pela química familiar desenvolvida entre Ralph Fiennes e o estreante Tony Revolori, ficamos sem tempo para reparar que Wes Anderson não consegue mesmo escapar à tendência de transformar cada um dos seus filmes numa casinha de bonecas (mesmo que este tenha menos daqueles planos dos objectos organizadinhos sobre a mesa).  Muito menos consegue evitar também gags totalmente falhados como o episódio da Sociedade das Chaves Cruzadas,  que serve só mesmo para convocar Bill Murray e assim arrecadar os pontos de "coolness" que essa presença traz.

The unflappable Wes Anderson makes his prettiest movie to date, exploring familiar themes in settings more expansive than ever.

This movie brings to perfection all of the elements of Anderson's quirky style -- his meticulous creation of a slightly demented world, his vivid and geometric art direction, heightened and somewhat melodramatic directing style, contained and hilarious set-pieces, singular and eccentric characters, and a very intense focus upon the particular. His ensemble cast delivers scene after scene of delight and reimagined history of the fading of a Europe that may never have been. Anderson creates nostalgia as an end in itself.

Storyteller/Director Wes Anderson (The Royal Tenenbaums, The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou) without fail would be one of my favourite directors, his artistic eye for detail and storytelling has a life all of its own, he has a way to draw you in and keep you engaged even when there is really nothing happening, with his unique style of camera work and his absolutely gorgeous locations, he has a unique ability to reinvent colour so that his sets are a world within themselves and so inviting.
The Grand Budapest Hotel is a tale within a tale within a tale, the film begins acknowledging that on the farthest eastern boundary of the Eastern continent: The former republic of Zubrowka once the seat of an Empire a young girl walks up to and stands in front of a monument covered in hotel keys and holders, she reaches into her pocket and adds her own. A plaque reads "Author" "in honour of our National treasure, she reaches into her pocket and pulls out a book with "The Grand Budapest Hotel written across its front, she then turns the book over to reveal a black and white picture of the "Author". The picture turns to colour and the Author begins narrating the story from behind his desk in 1985. He begins to tell the story of a hotel he once visited many years earlier in 1968 the hotel of course was The Grand Budapest. Set in a fictitious place the hotel stood in Alpine Alps somewhere in Europe. The young Author talks about how the once Grand Budapest hotel is now in a dire state, run down and looking a lot worse for wear. Whilst bathing he meets the current owner a mysterious and sad looking man, he soon learns this man is the current owner, he learns that he was once the richest man in the world who owned all the riches one could ever imagine. The owner invites the author to a meal and begins to tell his story. The owner agrees and begins to tell his tale of how he arrived and now owns the Grand Budapest Hotel. Flash back to 1932 and the owner now a young lobby boy begins the tale once more for the author he begins to fill the ears of the Author as he is whisked away to another time and into a life of murder, theft, love, sex, art and riches.....
Visually this story is stunning, plot wise the story telling is masterful, the camera shots used are vibrant and gorgeous, the score is an absolute journey from begging to end, the humour is endless, a little dark in places but still very typical of Wes Anderson's style. At times it did run a little slow in places but not enough to take anything negative. The cast was huge, so many big well-known names and every one of them played their character perfectly. Ralph Fiennes (Clash of the Titans, The Hurt Locker) as Monsieur Gustave H, was brilliant darling so charismatic and lovable. Tony Revolori (very new to the movie world) as Young Zero Moustafa was also amazing as Gustave H right hand man. F. Murray Abraham (Scarface, Amadeus) as Old Zero Moustafa. Adrien Brody (The Pianist, King Kong) as the vile Dmitri Desgoffe und Taxis, Willem Dafoe (The English Patient, Spider-Man) as J.G. Jopling Dmitri's right hand assassin. Jeff Goldblum (Jurassic Park, Independence Day) as Deputy Vilmos Kovacs, add to this already amazing ensemble Tilda Swinton, Edward Norton, Jude Law, Bill Murray, Harvey Keitel and a plethora of other very big names and you start to get an idea at how big this film really is. You would think having so many huge names could only equal bigger egos and a total mess, but it is the complete opposite.
I loved The Grand Budapest Hotel it is unlike Wes Andersons other film in the sense that this one has much more of a plot which of course only helps. I would recommend this for anyone who can look beyond big bangs and actually enjoy a real film. If your idea of a great film is Die Hard or something else as crass and pointless I wouldn't bother because you actually need to be slightly intellectual to really enjoy this one. Better yet if you don't like films with subtitles stay away, not that this has any it'll just make you think more than you normally would like to.

Wes Anderson delivers a film that is presented in one of the most unique ways i have seen especially in modern cinema. Everything from the dialogue to the amazingly unique shooting techniques have been carefully thought out and refined to create this comedic and heart felt film. The acting performances were all very distinct and all very well portrayed by the actors. The standout performances being Ralph Fiennes and Tony Revolori, one putting in one of the better performances of his career and the other making himself known to the world with this amazing debut to film. This film had a very different and specific style of humour that is not typically used in modern comedies. This both helped to film but i think also slightly hurt it. It did take a little while to understand the humour the director was going for, but once i did it became more clear how it was being used with the overall plot. The plot was an interesting one that takes you back through time and doesn't spend too long in a single location, which really helps to move the film along quickly and provide a variety of scenery. In the end it is the directing techniques used by Wes Anderson that really make this film shine. - 8.3

Best of Wes' work till date. Its like seeing the actors in comedy which you have not seen before. Characters are funny and concrete. Performances are top notch. Ralph should prepare his speech for Oscars.
fantastic movie with a wonderful cast loved it

I'm not the biggest Wes Anderson fan, which definitely skews my opinion, but in spite of being as annoyingly eccentric as his other work, The Grand Budapest Hotel is nothing if not an entertaining hour-and-a-half (its brevity works wonders for it). It crosses the border into sheer camp four times over, but Ralph Fiennes holds it all together through sheer force of charisma. While I'm all for a big cast in general, the decision to populate even the smallest roles with the likes of Bill Murray and Owen Wilson is incredibly distracting, as none save perhaps Willem Dafoe get anything resembling a memorable character. But it stays fun, is surely memorable, and has its odd moment of poignancy; you'd have to be made of stone to deny that.
I'm glad I didn't pay money to see this silly movie. I can see the appeal that it would have to some people but it doesn't work for me.

Wes Anderson has a style. Some may not understand it, but most even still, will love it. A master of dry humor, and it only gets more evident with every film he makes. Something about The Grand Budapest Hotel just might make it his masterpiece.

Take all the main elements of all his previous films, boil them down to their purest forms and mix them together and this is what will result. This film is not without its humorous moments, but its true charm comes in the aforementioned visual style. I almost have the feeling that this was the film Wes Anderson wanted to make all along . . .

A quirky little tale that was inspired by the writings of Austrian novelist Stefan Zweig. I have never heard of this guy and I don't know of his work (as far as I'm aware), so unfortunately I cannot comment any further on this movies accuracy adapting or being influenced by Zweig's work. What I do know is to expect all the trademark Wes Anderson quirks from plot themes visual style and of course casting that we have all become accustomed too. Now I will admit this does kinda bother me somewhat as I find this sort of repetition, mainly in his casting, a tad mundane and unadventurous, or at least it can lead to that (Tim Burton).  

Luckily this movies theme and visual direction grabbed my attention...well mainly the visuals. The story begins with flashbacks within flashbacks as a young girl starts to read from a memoir written by the 'author' (Tom Wilkinson). The memoir recounts a tale about a trip he made to the Grand Budapest Hotel back in 1968, the younger version of the author played by Jude Law. The young author meets up with the aging hotel owner played by F. Murray Abraham and they discuss how he became the owner. This in turn leads to another flashback to 1932 as we see the young hotel owner as a lobby boy under the tutelage of the hotel concierge played by Ralph Fiennes.

The movie is basically a Germanic/eastern European wartime murder mystery split into five chapters. An wealthy elderly hotel guest dies and leaves Fiennes character (Gustave) a valuable painting much to the anger of her odious money grabbing relatives. It is then discovered the old woman has been murdered and Fiennes is a prime suspect. What follows from there is a madcap vintage slapstick of a black comedy as we tag along with Gustave and his lobby boy Zero as they attempt to evade dangerous relatives, soldiers and prison (long story short).

So as I said for me this movie grabbed my attention through its unique visual style which kinda reminded me of classic murder mysteries but in a very Germanic sense. You could maybe drawn comparisons to the comedy 'Clue'? visually at least...kinda. The actual hotel surrounding background and the funicular are a highly detailed models which are based on real locations in the Czech Republic (the hotel anyway). I adored these models because they simply looked fantastic, admittedly obvious models but that's the appeal...it looks like a model railway set. The cold snowy terrain and weather really gives this movie a warm cozy atmosphere, the cutesy models, highly decorative traditional interior sets (very continental) and characters that look like your old relations all combine to give this almost Christmas glow to the proceedings...or it could just be me.

This sumptuous visual flair is helped along by the colour scheme of certain sequences such as the hotel being a light shade of pink making it look like a large cake. The interiors are also bright and colourful as are the staff uniforms in that classic 30's style. The fact that young Zero's girlfriend also works at the local bakery making fluffy mouth-watering pastel coloured baked treats almost feels like Anderson is teasing us. On top of that the bakery van is also a deliciously looking light shade of pink making you literately think of nothing but pink icing marshmallows and cakes! Its tantamount to torture I tells ya! 

On the flip side the fictional war aspect of the tale which is set in between the two great wars (1932) clearly looks and feels like WWI but it isn't...I don't think. Despite the whimsical vibe there are still beatings murder and oppression in some forms in the latter half of the movie, nothing hideous but enough to jolt you out of your cozy spot. I guess the real problem for me was the casting...yes that's right the casting. The movie is based around European aristocracy, puffed up rich continental types with fat moustaches that you'd normally see living currently in certain areas of north London. The issue is they are all played by very American actors and it doesn't really gel half the time.

Fiennes is easily the best thing going here and he fits his role perfectly with his own upper crust upbringing. His performance is both charming and amusing with his suave debonair persona as he greets and sucks up to the guests...then all of a sudden blammo!...he'll drop an F-bomb outta nowhere...brilliant! Kudos also to his sidekick played by Tony Revolori who looks just the ticket as the young alert lobby boy, dude looks like Penfold (Danger Mouse). There are various other decent performances throughout (too many cast members to mention) but its the odd characters played by Edward Norton, Jeff Goldblum, Harvey Keitel, Bill Murray, Adrien Brody, Jason Schwartzman and Owen Wilson (basically the entire American cast) that just don't work. The only American that does slot in well is Dafoe as the assassin who basically looks like Count Orlok once again...so yes that fits into this era and region perfectly.

These characters are meant to be Europeans in a small landlocked alpine country...yet they have American accents! plus some of these stars don't really do a great job performance wise either. You do get the impression Anderson revels in collecting a large glittering ensemble cast that looks stunning on paper and the movie posters but don't necessarily fit the bill. Plus I also get the impression Anderson kinda likes to play dress up with these big stars and not worrying so much about their characters, after all this whole movie does tend to look like an illustrated children's book or an explosion from within a toy box (with layers of pink icing on top). 

Essentially the story is about greed I guess, on the surface everything seems sweet and pleasant but dig down and really everybody is a bit of a shit and not to be trusted...including Gustave to a degree. I'm not even sure if I liked any of the characters really, I suppose the lobby boy is our (the viewers) most trusted ally. In the end the movie ends on a happy note or so you think, Anderson finally slaps you across the face as the very ending is actually quite sad and grim like some kind of children's fairytale. Its an odd one for sure, starts off like as a feel good flick...visually looking like everything is taking place within a snow globe, but slowly grinds you down until you feel like sobbing at the finale. I still can't really decide if I actually liked it or not, its certainly well made directed and crafted but its not what I thought it would be. I must give kudos to Anderson for his creation and storytelling (even though it all feels a tad ostentatious) but I still can't help but feel somewhat empty and emotionless towards it even though I really really wanted to love it.

Wes Anderson "The Gran Budapest Hotel" represents the highest peak in this director style. The film outstanding art direction and cinematography is one of the biggest attraction, as well a powerful ensemble cast.

"The Gran Budapest Hotel" tales the story of Gustave H (Ralph Fiennes) a well known concierge in this hotel in the 1920's. Zero Mustafa (F. Murray Abraham/Tony Revolori) recounts the events from his own point of view as well his relationship with Gustave H. This legendary concierge was demanded by rich old ladies that visit the hotel for the luxury of the place as well how Gustave carter them in so many ways. One of the visitors Madame D (Tilda Swinton) was in love of the famous concierge, for a wide variety of reasons, she also offer Gustave all her fortune if she dies.

Suddenly after Madame D last visit, came the sad news that she die Gustave is included as part of the will which upset all the members of the family including her son Dmitri Desgoffe-und-Taxis.

The story will takes place in interesting passages of Gustave in jail as well well crafted actions scenes and chase.

"The Gran Budapest Hotel" is not a powerful story like older films from Wes Anderson, but is a delightful film paying tribute to the silent films era with cinematic techniques, beautiful art direction, costume design and a powerful assemble cast.

Anderson's films are very easy to spot - a still picture is normally enough to figure it's his work. The colors, the synchronicity, the humor or the fast pace and dialogue.

This film is not the easiest to hang on too. It goes fast, and there are many characters here. None of them feel very interesting to me, I just don't care very much about them. As always there are loads of famous faces - it's fun to spot them and remember their earlier roles. The looks of it is brilliant, often original (even Anderson-origina) and it's just lovely. The story is much poorer for me and I don't seem to care much - I'm constantly waiting for something bigger. Few laughs but also few really dull moments. The biggest flaw here is that it never gripped me as the viewer, and it's better features is the amazing production and the looks of it, plus all the cool actors.

Wes Anderson's downward curve seem to continue for me. Hopefully it will rise again soon.

It's hard for me to get into Wes Anderson's films but this one was actually enjoyable for me.  My favorite of his work.

Basic: So, there is a lot of plotting going on in this film, but anyway, the story starts off where a young girl, who's reading a book called, "The Grand Budapest Hotel", which is made by the author (Tom Wilkinson), and then it flips back to the author a little bit, and then it flips back to 1968, of a writer (Jude Law), that he met a person named Zero(F. Murray Abraham), and then it flips back to 1932 of where the young Zero (Newcomer Tony Revolori), who's a lobby boy, and spends his time at The Grand Budapest Hotel. Then, lastly, it spends almost the rest of the film on M. Gustave (Ralph Fiennes), and young Zero of where both of them get involved into murder, theft, and also into some big adventures as well. It's like a box inside a box inside a box inside a box.

What's the deal: I wouldn't say that I am a big fan of Wes Anderson, but it doesn't mean that I disliked his work. There are things that I like about it his work. He knows how to make a great soundtrack in his movies, and he's also a filmmaker, that does so much style, and creativity. In fact, I've only seen two of his movies. The first one, was Fantastic Mr. Fox, which I had a good time watching it from start to finish, and then somebody recommended me to watch Rushmore, which it's a classic coming-of-age film, and I actually enjoyed it. Now for his newest film, The Grand Budapest Hotel, I've to say that this one is more than to be liked. Truly, and being honest to myself, that I really like this film, and there are things that I really like about it. The settings and the shots of it are very exquisite and very colorful enough. I do believe that it's gonna win some Oscars for that. The storytelling devices in the film are super creative, but what I think of what makes it even greater is how both the story, and the characters are so effective, and outrageous. The film does have a great screenplay by Wes Anderson, which it is the best screenplay he has ever written, and it's very humorous, and absolutely brilliant. Plus, the cast is fantastic. Ralph Fiennes, who I see him in serious roles rather than comedic roles, but he actually carried a lot of humor and a sense of awe through this whole movie. Tony Revolori does have a lot of talent, while Saoirse Ronan is getting better and better of her acting. They do make a great relationship to each other. F. Murray Abraham does carry some big emotions in the film, and the rest of the cast, well done job. The pacing does come off fast, but I don't have a problem with it. The ending is pretty emotional, and even though I don't like sad ending, this type of ending does make me feel satisfy. Alexandre Desplat's music is amazing. Milena Canonero's costumes look beautiful. Right now, I've seen it three times, and I still really like the film a lot.  

My full opinion: The Grand Budapest Hotel is probably the most marvelous film by Wes Anderson, and it's also one that takes you in a silly, joyful, and breathtaking ride. 9.7/10

El gran hotel Budapest  [2014]

Loaded with extremely high expectations even before being released, The Grand Hotel Budapest is a typical cult Wes Anderson delivery which will either make you love or hate it. Completely polarizing, it is an absurd, frenzy story, with elements of black comedy which actually is quite thoughtful. 

Even though the movie's name suggests that the hotel and what happens there between the two world wars would be the center of the story, director Wes Anderson takes a completely different approach. The Grand Hotel is only a partial background for Zero Moustafa's (Toni Revolori) life and adventures as a lobby boy. Hired by Mr. Gustave (Ralph Fiennes) , the iconic concierge of The Grand Hotel Budapest, Zero gets involved in a frenzy adventure to, falls in love and grows up as a person amidst a battle for a huge family fortune. 

To many the story would seem a bit too scattered and silly, while the character might be seen as too quirky. However, those familiar with Wes Anderson's style and previous deliveries would expect exactly this from the movie!  His typical dark humor, references to the not-so-far-yet-forgotten-past and tributes to the classical film-making are to be observed all over his delivery. Every single shot and frame is nostalgic. Even the actors and their performances are marked by the Wes Anderson's love for the cinematic history. Speaking of acting, the huge list of A-star Hollywood names is a pleasure to be observed simply because everyone is so unique in his or her old-school character. Needless to say, above all is Ralph Fiennes, who character of a player, seducer of old women, yet a perfectionist when it comes to his profession and to hotel management. 

Given the track record of Wes Anderson, The Grand Hotel Budapest is hard to be considered his best delivery. Simply because he has no bad movie and all of them have been an example of classic film-making. That is why, by saying that The Grand Budapest Hotel is another Wes Anderson delivery that matches his standard is simply enough to make this movie a must see !

The stylistic imagery and incredible production design of Wes Anderson has been promoted by this film in both a mesmorizinly beautiful and comedic way. While the plot and screenplay is driven very fast and some aspects of the film's overall story feel a little too broad, I was continually fixated on the visual elements of this film. Brillaint costume design and stunning acting from a large talented cast is able to deter away some of the film's less noteworthy aspects such as its anti-climatic ending. While the film definitely has its emotional and comedic show stoppers, the ending felt very flat, as if the film just ended without an concluding stunner. We always knew the ending, and though the means to getting to there were twisting and exciting, it would have been nice to end on something a bit more groundbreaking and suspensful. The real star of this film though has to be Wes Anderson whose thoughtful, precise yet visually brave direction leads to film into a new style of modern cinema. Something a little different with its various settings, unique effects, deep themes and extravagant design, Grand Budapest may not be as groundbreaking or dramatic as it tries, and could have been, however with a perfect lead performance from Ralph Fiennes, this film is able to create its own path and ultimately can still stick out from the busy arthouse genre with films that are becoming so similar and unexciting these days.
Appealing visually with interesting, eccentric characters, the film drags along perplexingly, eventually arriving at a forgettable conclusion.

Self aware and stuck repeating a simple code, the camera loses its power as a tool to expand the subconscious or overall tone of a scene. There is no doubt that Wes Anderson is a master story teller. His films are charming to a degree that we can only describe as being in love with his films. But his latest endeavor, The Grand Budapest Hotel, stinks of cuteness. He must have shared notes with Tim Burton regarding one's own stylistic choices, because his pseudo-expressionism borders on self-parody.

It's refreshing to see Ralph Finnes play a character who isn't evil, corrupted, dark, or whatever variation on evil there is. I found his character to be a bit much. In the past, we've dealt with characters who have had foils that I can personally relate to. Royal Tenenbaum was an asshole who was never close to his family, while Scout Master Ward in Moonrise Kingdom feared being a failure. I could not latch on to the suave, over the top M. Gustav. The best acting moments came when Gustave would simply declare "fuck it" or a moment when (SPOILER) someone is pushed off of a cliff (END SPOILER). The only character I found truly fascinating was Agatha and unfortunately, she served only as a romantic partner and reason for Zero to step up to the plate in the film's third act.

Wes Anderson's direction coupled with Robert D. Yeoman's cinematography are without a doubt the most memorable aspects of the film, certainly more so than the performances or the interweaving story (which I found not to be too interesting). The scenes with Jeff Goldblum and Willem Dafoe are gorgeously lit and beautifully shot. Anderson moves the camera around like a dream, creating suspense simply through movement as opposed to using body language or the POV of the characters in that scene.

After falling in love with Wes Anderson with his previous work, I found The Grand Budapest Hotel to be a self indulgent bore fest. Don't get me wrong, this film is not bad and I'm happy that an independent release of this nature was able to find main stream success, but simply put, this movie is "too Wes Anderson." It oozes his style, as I had mentioned before, to the point of self parody and slight groans every time the camera panned to the left or right of a focal point.

This is as Ralph Fiennes as a comedy starring Ralph Fiennes can guy.  Such "proper" humor, deliciously elegant in its delivery.  It's not my thing, though I will say it's one of the prettiest movies you'll ever see.

I am generally not a fan of Wes Anderson's strange style, but this was absolutely hilarious in a twisted and wacky way. The impeccable acting and dark humor delivered flawlessly by Ralph Fiennes  is perfect. This is a strange movie but it is well worth the journey.

This film is too clever by half.  One never knows whether it's parody or slapstick vaudeville.  Despite a superb cast, I found it boring and silly.  The purpose of a period piece is to teach some history and show off some beautiful period sets, but while this film has beautiful sets, it is divorced from history as it is set in an unknown country and at an unknown time and features mostly-American actors employing strange and incongruous accents.  The movie got really silly and tedious in its long, spy-thriller, Mission Impossible-style scenes of escape and networked communication.  Again, too clever by half.  It wasn't worth my time.  Credit, however, to the actors and the set department for making a little something out of a poorly-conceived story and a less-than-stellar script.  That said, Ed Norton was wasted in this film, and it's slightly upsetting to see a brilliant actor like Norton reduced to taking roles like the one he played in The Grand Budapest Hotel.

Above all, the plotline offers the perfect platform for presenting the most outrageous situations with utmost seriousness. The dialogue is brilliant. You can't beat a line like "She was shaking like a shitting dog". Only in Wes Anderson's world...

The Grand Budapest Hotel definitely has that quirky charm that we've all come to expect from Wes Anderson movies. Plus, it's impossible to dislike Ralph Fiennes' portrayal of unflinching propriety in the face of disagreeable circumstances. This is probably in my top three Wes Anderson movies.

Everyone loves a great storyteller. One that can intertwine humor, wit, charm, intrigue, nostalgia, and grandeur with great ease. And that's where The Grand Budapest Hotel achieves on so many levels. It has all of the above and more. A great story told by a great storyteller.

I would call this movie a hybrid. It is part murder mystery, part comedy, and part period piece all at the same time. It has something for everyone. So to say this is a movie that is unique is quite an understatement. You have never seen a movie like this, I have never seen a movie like it either, and I gobbled it up with pure glee.

The movie has an overwhelming cast of great actors: Jeff Goldblum, Willem Dafoe, Adrien Brody, Edward Norton, and many many more. Usually when you assemble such a fantastic team of actors, it does not quite work. Some movies treat them as cameos and never really get much from them. Or one might outshine another. Or even worse, none might shine at all.

But this movie gets it right. No character feels out of place, and believe you me, there are a lot of A-list celebrity actors who play different characters, yet they all seem to mesh so well. Why you ask? Because first and foremost, this is a great story and script. The acting is top notch. The dialogue is brilliant and comedy gold. 

The characters hilariously chat up a storm, oblivious to the here and now so much so it puts their lives in danger. The dialogue between Zero Mustafa, played by Tony Revolori and Gustave, played by Ralph Fiennes, is majestic, magnificent, and mirthful. Add this to a who's who of actors, a wonderful and alluring plot, great acting, and you end up with a must see movie for all.

In the Republic of Zubrowka, a European alpine state ravaged by war and poverty, a young writer (Jude Law) discovers that the remote mountainside hotel has fallen on hard times. Many of its lustrous facilities are now in a poor state of repair, and its guests are few. The writer encounters the hotel's elderly owner, Zero Moustafa (F. Murray Abraham), one afternoon, and they agree to meet later that evening. Over dinner in the hotel's enormous dining room, Mr. Moustafa tells him the tale of how he took ownership of the hotel and why he is unwilling to close it down. The story begins in 1932 during the hotel's glory days when the young Zero (Tony Revolori) was a lobby boy. Zubrowka is on the verge of war, but this is of little concern to Monsieur Gustave H. (Ralph Fiennes), the Grand Budapest's devoted concierge. The owner of the hotel is unknown and only relays important messages through lawyer Deputy Kovacs (Jeff Goldblum). When he is not attending to the needs of the hotel's wealthy clientele or managing its staff, Gustave courts a series of aging women who flock to the hotel to enjoy his "exceptional service". One of the ladies is Madame Céline Villeneuve "Madame D" Desgoffe und Taxis (Tilda Swinton), and Gustave spends the night with her prior to her departure. One month later, he is informed that Madame D has died under mysterious circumstances. Taking Zero along, he races to her wake and the reading of the will, where Kovacs, coincidentally the executor of the will, reveals that she had bequeathed Gustave Boy with Apple, a very valuable painting, in her will. This enrages her family, all of whom hoped to inherit it. Her son, Dmitri Desgoffe und Taxis (Adrien Brody) lashes out at Gustave. With the help of Zero, Gustave takes the painting and returns to the Grand Budapest, securing the painting in the hotel's safe. During the journey, Gustave makes a pact with Zero: in return for the latter's help, he makes Zero his heir. Shortly thereafter, Gustave is arrested and imprisoned for the murder of Madame D after forced testimony by Serge X (Mathieu Amalric), Madame D's butler. Zero aids Gustave in escaping from Zubrowka's prison by sending a series of stoneworking tools concealed inside cakes made by Zero's fiancée Agatha (Saoirse Ronan). Along with a group of convicts, Gustave digs his way out of his cell. Gustave then teams up with Zero to prove his innocence... 

Wes Anderson is a director you either love or hate as I have said before, to be quite blunt. I had a hard time to accept his a bit too ambitious and "smarty pants" hipster sort movies at first, but with "Life Aquatic" and "Moonrise Kingdom" he managed to convince me with his theatrical colourful stories and his attention to details. I reckon "Moonrise Kingdom" is one of his best features, so I had high hopes for "Grand Hotel Budapest" as the positive reviews came pouring in. My first reaction after seeing the "Grand Hotel Budapest" was that is was to be honest a bit boring, stale, too long and it almost felt that he made it with just his left hand. With that I mean the storyline just didn´t engage me at least as his previous movies did. It´s a great cast, but the whole production feels more like an excuse for a fancy dress up party that really leads nowhere and all the characters has this deadpan look on their face throughout the movie. Yes, Fiennes makes an impression as Gustave H with his dry wit and farcical appearance which we are not used to see and it´s always a treat to see so many big names in one movie giving life to all these strange characters. But, to me this became a gigantic fancy soufflé that didn´t contain much more than just sugar in the end.

Perfect in its quirkiness, tells a stunningly dramatic tale with a light and at the same time very deep touch. Great performances from all actors, with Ralph Fiennes once more gifting us with a phenomenal performance

Toda a excentricidade de Wes Anderson ganha níveis de sofisticação absurdos nesse filme que é um exercício e, ao mesmo tempo, um desafio estético - com sua minúcia cirúrgica onde cada plano é de fato uma pintura (não por acaso esse é o elemento chave dentro da narrativa: um quadro). Anderson e seu inseparável Diretor de Fotografia, Robert Yeoman, brincam com cores e movimentos inesperados que terminam em enquadramentos simétricos cheios de profundidade de campo e elementos curiosos na composição do quadro.
Como se não bastasse, a história, mais profunda do que parece num primeiro momento, se utiliza de uma narrativa similar à de um conto infantil, hilária e cheia dos personagens sempre estranhos do diretor, interpretados por um elenco tão estelar (alguns fazem apenas 'cameos'!) que dá para pensar que trabalhariam de graça para ele. 
Filme espetacular!

Wow, what an utterly charming movie.   As I've mentioned before, Wes Anderson films are hit and miss for me, and this one hit in a big way.  I believe this is his best film to date and may even be his masterpiece.  It of course is teeming with his signature style and includes the typical group of kooky characters, but there is a melancholy about the story that resonated with me more than his other work.   This movie is brilliant for many reasons, but what makes it original is that it is so much at the same time:  it's a dark comedy, screwball comedy, crime caper, and a fairy tale (albeit more Hans Christian Anderson than Disney), and somehow it all blends together seamlessly.  The writing is fantastic and absolutely should at least be nominated for an Oscar:  the narrative is tight, the plot is fluid, and the dialogue is sublime.  It stars Anderson's usual army of A-list actors, and of course they are all great, but it's Tilda Swinton who steals the show, who only has two scenes but is somehow the standout performance.  Though I hate to even say that because Ralph Fiennes is perfect in the lead role (as well as newcomer Tony Revolori).   Who knew Fiennes had such great comedic timing?   This movie is beautiful, whimsical, stylish, sentimental, rich, quirky, and hilarious (the chase scene in particular had me in stitches!).  If you haven't already, you gotta see it.  The best movie I've seen so far this year.

Encountered this film while searching for films to watch during my first week of summer with my friend. The two posters we saw in the cinema walls were quite dull: one with a gallery of ancient photographs of people who we did not know of, and a large pink building in the centre in front of the misty mountains. We didn't expect anything from this film while entering the cinema... but turned out to be laughing and having the urge to watch the film again when leaving the theatre. "The Grand Budapest Hotel" directed by Wes Anderson, is a comedy film that revolves around the adventure of a posh concierge and his lobby boy during the first and second World Wars. As soon as the film began, I was attracted to the vivid colours, (especially pink), unique (ridiculously silly) characters that have cartoony characteristics and their humour, and the imaginary creative editing which I believe are the gems of this film. Every moment of the film did not stop from impressing me at all. I don't really remember what the sound design like, but I do remember that..back in summer when I knew this film was going to be shown on my flight, I resisted to watch it because I didn't want to watch this film on a tiny screen with headphones with too much noise around me. If I had the chance to watch this again.. I will go buy it and watch it. I am now pretty excited to purchase the DVD of this film and watch the "behind the scenes" . No regrets, amazing film, a good film if you want a good laugh.

I am beginning to totally dig Wes Anderson's style of directing. I like the quirkiness of his films like "The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou", "Moonrise Kingdom" and "The Darjeeling Limited"; he's makes the films seem so clever and even though it's not laugh-out-loud funny; there's plenty of humor in his film which I really enjoy. The cast in this film was superb: of course, Ralph Fiennes (M. Gustave) is my all-time favorite actor and was the sole reason I wanted to watch this film; but I was pleasantly surprised to discover that the other cast members are also some of my favorite actors. Tom Wilkinson (Author) is always a treat to watch, Adrien Brody (Dmitri) is just hubba-hubba in my book and it worth it even seeing s glimpse of him in any film. I also like Jude Law (the young writer), the wonderfully talented Saoirse Ronan (Agatha), the ubber cute Edward Norton (Henckels), the awesome Tilda Swinton (Madame D.) and the hilarious Bill Murray (M. Ivan). But I must admit, among the sea-of-talented actors, there were two standout performances and its coincidentally for the same character: F. Murray Abraham (M. Moustafa) and Tony Revolori (Zero). I mean, you expect a brilliant performance from Mr. Fiennes but Revolori complimented his performance so perfectly that it's hard to deny the chemistry between the two characters-- their like a matching set of salt-and-pepper shakers, you can't have one without the other. F. Murray Abraham, although his character doesn't appear with Mr. Fiennes', he portrayed the *****SPOILERS***** older version of Zero so convincingly that you just instantly fall in-love with him because he's the grandfather you've always wanted to have type of guy. He did a really terrific job! In fact, this film is probably one of the best films I've seen all year and the cast was so divine, there wasn't a miss-cast part in the entire film; they were all truly marvelous and the story was just awesome!!! Loved it, loved it!!!

Funny and amusingly quirky tale of the history of a famous hotel in a fictional land made to represent Europe in the early 20th century. 
The story centers around a talented hotel concierge and his young protege who both get caught up in the legal complications of the death of a wealthy noblewoman and must go on an elaborate journey to set things straight. These central characters along with nearly all of the others are infectiously fascinating with all of their strange nuances and mannerisms. The dialogue is often very frank and therefore, a bit strange and striking, but this style along with the slightly unorthodox yet compelling cinematography combine for a pleasingly bizarre experience. The style is one of the best qualities of the movie and never really gets old; however, it can at times seem a little artificial and awkward, despite its otherwise overwhelming success. The movie is also quite funny in many places both as a result of its unconventionality as well as its cleverness. 
While the overall style of the movie is by design eccentric and a bit absurd, the plot itself is coherent and very intriguing. In the end, I felt a sense of satisfying closure and delight in the sheer novelty and wit of this well-crafted movie.

Funny, bright, delicious and incredibly astute and ambicious. Wes Anderson's new masterpiece is just amazing. The incredible look of "The Grand Budapest Hotel" give to us an amazing story behind a great cast and unique crew!

Like a delicious fairy tale, the Grand Budapest Hotel is a gloriously over the top fantasy confection. It tells the story of a suave concierge, Gustave H. who has a taste for the older lady clients of the hotel where he works. Gustave takes a new lobby boy, Zero, under his wing to teach him the trade but the unlikely couple soon become embroiled in a case of murder and the theft of a priceless artwork. This film is hugely enjoyable and very funny. It has a cast of pantomime characters and preposterous situations that mean it occupies a world just slightly removed from reality however, it is utterly charming and brilliantly made. There's a stellar case with the likes of Tilda Swinton, Bill Murray, Ralph Fiennes, Jeff Goldblum, Adrien Brody, Jude Law, Willem Dafoe and F. Murray Abraham. Fiennes takes the lead role of Gustave H. with Tony Revolori as the young lobby boy, Zero. Fiennes plays his role with the perfect pitch, balancing deftly somewhere between pillar of the community and a bit of a cad. Revolori is great too managing to be wide-eyed innocent and a quick-thinking foil. The film looks opulent and sumptuous with its 1930s Eastern European setting giving it a suitably grand and exotic appearance. Wes Anderson handles the more slapstick and overtly comic moments well and directs with care and precision to make many scenes genuinely moving. It's a long time since I've seen a film that was this inventive, sharp and clever. I thoroughly enjoyed watching it and recommend it highly.
Beautifully, written, acted, designed, photographed and even the credits were worth watching.

I want to start off by saying, I think Wes Anderson produces some of the best trailers for his films.  I mean they really sell the quirky concept.  That said, I really wanted to like this film.  The trailer marketed it as a fast paced caper that just seemed too bent on Anderson-lunacies that it might have worked.  It doesn't fully come together, but it's still an entertaining piece thanks to Ralph Fiennes and Tony Revolori.  Even at a slim hour and 40 minutes, the story gets bogged down with too much meandering, side stories and cuteness and it almost becomes too complex for it's own simplicity of the payoff.  In the end, it comes off as a Tarantino meets Anderson if told as Life of Pi meets Inception.  Not an amazing film, but artistically is probably the best all year.

Wes Anderson produces another charming adventure in The Grand Budapest Hotel that is full of interesting characters.

We embark on a splendid adventure within The Grand Budapest Hotel told by Mr. Zero Moustafa, the one time lobby-boy and now lofty owner of the establishment. We travel back in time to the 1930?s at the hotel's peak of grandiosity to meet the beguiling M. Gustave, Zero's one time predecessor and mentor.  A battle of fortune and theft sets forward a monumental ordeal involving an insurmountable many.

M. Gustave is a meticulous man with a taste for the finest comforts in life. Ralph Fiennes plays the bourgeois concierge completely straight and, yet, is the source of most laughs in this comedy and is wonderful to watch. The rest of the film is a who's who of well-known actors in fully realized idiosyncratic character performances. Expect to see Edward Norton, Willem Dafoe, Jeff Goldblum, Jude Law, Tilda Swinton, Adrien Brody, among others we've grown accustomed in a Wes Anderson film, though I won't ruin the surprise.

When you look at the film in parts it is masterful. The visuals and sets are luxuriously stunning, beyond anything you could imagine and a dream. The acting is top notch and characters intriguing. The story is entertaining and funny and especially unique. The music by Alexandre Desplat is charming and complementary. And yet, I feel as though the film doesn't come together as Mr. Anderson wished.

Wes Anderson films tend to be rife with characters and plot lines. The Grand Budapest Hotel jumps from each strand without fully completing or connecting at its conclusion, especially in regard to minor characters.

While thoroughly enjoyable and charming as a film, if more time were taken to develop some subplots, remove others, and intertwine the rest, The Grand Budapest Hotel would easily have been one of Wes Anderson's finest creations.
Arguably Wes Anderson's most strikingly stylistic film, The Grand Budapest Hotel is vibrant, creative and intelligent in its craft to contrast with its brilliant performances.

This is my favourite Wes Anderson film by a country mile but that's not saying much as I'm not a fan of his previous work as I've never quite got his humour so to speak. Set in between the world wars in the 1900s Gustave (Feinnes) is the concierge at the prestigious Grand Budapest Hotel. He is the king of his craft and everybody warms to him and especially so the wealthy females of shall we say the more senior variety. One of these is Madame D (Swinton) who passes away and leaves Gustave a rare painting called Boy With Apple in her will. This does not go down well with her family and Gustave along with his faithful bell boy Zero steal the painting. This leads to a chase with the authorities suspecting foul play in Madame Ds death with Gustave the chief suspect. Also interested in the painting is Jopling (Dafoe) who seems to be a member of Madame Ds family or a hitman or both. There is also a ridiculous prison escape and a bonkers shootout in the hotel.


What can you say about a cast that boasts the likes of Ralph Fiennes, Tilda Swinton, Jeff Goldblum, Willem Dafoe, Jude Law, Harvey Keitel and Edward Norton (to name but a few)? Stellar casting and all are good without exception. Ralph Feinnes is particularly funny in the lead role and this surprised me as I wouldn't have listed comedy as one of his major strengths. I particularly liked Norton's policeman and Jeff Goldblum and Willem Dafoe also gave performances that I liked.


I liked this a lot more than I thought I would and the prison escape was particularly funny. Not laugh out loud belly laughs or anything like that but very enjoyable nonetheless. Maybe the Grand Budapest Hotel represents a turning of the corner for me and Mr Anderson and for this reason I await his next offering with a new found positivity.

Wes Anderson's latest is not among his best; in fact, it could perhaps even be mistaken as a parody of his style. The world is imaginative, the tone deadpan, the cast an endless parade of talent - yet for all the bells and whistles it remains the shell of a Wes Anderson movie, devoid of the usual wit and deep humanity of "Rushmore," "The Royal Tenenbaums," or even "Fantastic Mr. Fox" and "Moonrise Kingdom." In its place is an abundance of oddness for the sake of oddness - we have a miscast Ralph Fiennes as Gustave (a role in which Peter Sellers would have killed); an annoying amount of colloquial "fucks" said by otherwise urbane characters, weirdly off-color and un-funny jokes about Gustave's sexuality, and a far-too-busy score by Alexandre Desplat which never gives you a moment to breathe. Yes, the design and cinematography is beautiful; Anderson's imagination creates a seemingly-endless amount of gorgeously quirky visuals, but without the heart and the wit it becomes a nauseating assault. He wants to make a statement about basic goodness in the face of a hardening world, but after the endless chases through dollhouse sets, the neverending bobsled race, and the paint-by-numbers parade of cameos by Anderson regulars, the sentiment feels tacked on and the film becomes the most un-Wes Anderson thing of all - disingenuous.
Quirky and fun, but still left lot more on the table and didn't  deliver to its full potential given the strong cast...

The whole movie runs with a set pace, a rather fast pace unlike in The Royal Tenenbaums. Gustave and Zero are set in motion right through the film and the end of narration maintains the motion. Anderson has been very successful in not letting the drama seep through the plot to spoil its comic nature. Frugal with dialogues, actions maintain the momentum in the film. 
Sets, costume, cinematography, screenplay, direction- everything is signature Wes Anderson. I liked this film because of its simplicity. Anderson presenta una película en la que en cada secuencia, cada escena, cada toma, cada movimiento de cámara y cada color exudan elegancia, belleza, cuidado, detallismo y bueno... arte. La huella que deja el estilo de este director es imborrable y repleta de encanto y personalidad.

Las interpretaciones son soberbias, y la historia es naturalmente colorida, entretenida, divertida y muy británica.

Su exquisita trama y su desarrollo narrativo son cuidadosos, se encuentran compuestos por una serie de Matrioskas (muñecas rusas), a saber cuál más repleta de contenido que la otra.

Los diálogos, elegantes paradójicamente hasta en las palabras más cochambrosas, son capaces de sacarle a la audiencia sonoras carcajadas.

'Hotel Budapest' se siente como un dulce fino e importado. Con una envoltura vistosa, un recubrimiento fuerte y un centro ácido, capaz de estimular al paladar... de generar ligeras corrientes que te hacen saltar y querer más.

The Grand Budapest Hotel is a classic Wes Anderson film, blending beautiful scenery with stoic acting and cut-throat glamorized dialogue. It is amusing to watch, exciting to be immersed in, and yet it feels too staged and rehearsed. Although it comes with the style, it feels like Wes Anderson is now trying too hard to repeat what was his previous successes. It is an entertaining film, but feels sporadic, not as witty or intelligent as his greats, and struggles to truly connect with the audience. Compared to standard films, it is far above average, but compared to what Anderson is capable of, it is slightly disappointing.

"The Grand Budapest Hotel" is a movie that had piqued my interests ever since it was first announced. It was Wes Anderson, but seemed more serious than "MoonRise Kingdom" or my favorite of his "The Royal Tenenbaums." And for me, a Anderson lover, this wasn't necessarily a good thing. His more serious films, "Darjeeling Limited," were my least favorites of his.So this worried me indecently. But the cast looked great, i do love Saoirse Ronan, and the art style looked like Anderson on steroids. A whole building with his quirky decorating style? Sign me up! So i decided to give "Budapest" a try. And i was not disappointed. The visuals drip with atmosphere and color. Soft, muted colors, but colors all the same. The aspect ratio also flips back and forth, a small but notable touch. When it is in our time, it's full widescreen. A few years back, it's the annoying stretched thin version, and in the main story, it's fullscreen. This is just the first, but most perfect example of Anderson's great attention to detail. The whole film is more emotional than his others, but still manages to have the chuckle friendly style that has persisted all of his films. And the cast is wonderful! Ralph Fiennes completely owns his character and Tony Revolori, the young newcomer who plays Zero, couldn't have asked for a better first film. The details, which are what Anderson does best, are abundant here. But the real stars, (weirdly enough) are not his typicals; dialogue, details, art style. The real stars are his characters. Not since "Tenenbaums" has there been such richly created Anderson characters. And that is what makes "The Grand Budapest Hotel" a place worth staying at. At least for a while. 5/5

I've liked the other Wes Anderson movies I've seen, but have always had little niggling problems that stopped me loving them. Here, however, no niggles.

Great use of various aspect ratios, while maintaining his meticulous approach to framing. With most films viewed in 4:3 (rare nowadays, I know) cut down from widescreen, it's interesting to see such a beautiful conscious use of the smaller screen. It's so well done I didn't even notice it at first.

Also, great performances by a perfectly cast ensemble (the mix of accents doesn't even bother me in this case), especially Ralph Fiennes in the lead, whose harried concierge is very different to anything else I've seen him play, but handled with just as much skill.

Great movie all round.

This is a pretty good movie but I thought it would be better. It wasn't as funny as i thought it would be and at times it was kinda boring. Overall it was a pretty good movie only worthy of three stars

#movies A big hotel situated in the fictional Republic of Zubrowka used to be very popular and luxurious place many years ago. But now it can boast of only few visitors, its glorious days are a thing of the past. There is a certain writer (Jude Law) among the people who are living in the hotel and one day he he happens to meet the present hotel owner called Mr. Zero Moustafa (F. Murray Abraham). Naturally he seems to be very rich and powerful and it is with much shyness the writer dares to ask him how Moustafa became the hotel owner and how much money he paid for it. As I have mentioned the young writer is eager to ask questions and know such things. To his astonishment he hears that the hotel owner paid nothing. In addition Moustafa seems to lack in a good listener and wish to share the story of his life with somebody. In fact Mr. Moustafa is an old man and obviously needs communication even more than the writer himself. So he starts telling his story. 
Many years ago Zero (can you believe it?) was a lobby boy at the same hotel. He was an immigrant and had no proper documents. But the chief manager called Gustave agreed to give him a trial. In a short time Zero proved to be very smart, helpful and useful and Gustave realized he could trust the boy in everything. Gustave was a sort of the perfect hotel manager to tell you the truth. But he had one peculiar feature - he had a lot of lovers, mainly they were rich, elderly and lonely ladies who stayed at Grand Budapest Hotel. One day all of a sudden Gustave learnt his lover Madame D. had died unexpectedly after just leaving the hotel some weeks before. 
Read more http://www.viewforum.net/movie-stunned-me-150/grand-budapest-hotel-3954/#post6598

What may be his crowing achievement, The Grand Budapest Hotel employs the techniques and stylistic flourishes we have all come to expect from a Wes Anderson film. Not only is the film fun to look at through its immaculately crafted camera work and cotton candy color palate of soft pastels, I was also delighted by the ever so sharply written dialog. With a barrage of characters both great and small, concerning their inclusion, Grand Budapest is both a sweeping and intimate portrayal of a bygone era and the love and friendship between two men told in the off beat and quirky way only Anderson could conjure.

From the very first frame, any cinephile would know this was a Wes Anderson film and while his signature style is apparent in almost every shot, each of his films has a very different feel. The madcap creativity on display is gleefully intoxicating. Not as outwardly funny as Fantastic Mr. Fox or The Royal Tenenbaums and strangely one of his most macabre at moments, The Grand Budapest Hotel unfolds in a unique and entrancing fashion with Anderson's typical visual splendor. He remains in my top 3 favorite filmmakers working today.
Best film I've seen this year bar none.

This was lovely cinematography. I felt like I was a child reading a very colorful book with pop ups and scratch n sniff sections for the cakes n sweets throughout. This is visually stimulating and it was also a pretty cool story. If they concentrated more on the writing and not so much the visuals.. this would be an easy 4 stars in my opinion. Overall, I was pleased.
Brilliant film: historically interesting, characters are delightfully complex, quirky. Unpredictable story. Sets and costumes: confectionary.
A must watch! Every frame is a piece of art..

Another great movie from Wes Anderson.  While the movie isn't his best work or as good as his last film ,moonrise kingdom,it's still a very good movie with some great performances, amazing imagery, and unique story.  If some of the dialogue was sharper and Funnier it would have been his best yet.
My new least favorite Wes Anderson movie. All camera shots, no story, no acting, no heart, no soul. Like watching someone just randomly flip pages of a 1932 encyclopedia. The worst.

As is often the case with a modern Wes Anderson movie, the cinematography and the general use of the camera is fantastic.
There is a great amount of visual detail, and artistic style everywhere. However some stylistic elements reminded me too much of Tim Burton, which is a bad thing.

Quite a few funny/quirky moments, which were necessary for an otherwise pretty lame story. There were some gross and unnecessary elements to the plot, that worked to it's detriment.
Acting was great, although, as befits the director's style, it was very subdued.

It's always funny when a character prioritizes a display of their personality over a more practical course of action, and Anderson tends to do this a lot, but there was at least one scene in this one where it goes too far and too long and just left me a lot less immersed, and a little bit annoyed.

No great moral to this story either, from what I saw.

The Grand Budapest Hotel is a work of art everyone must see. It is all about how this hotel came to be owned by Mr. Moustafa (F. Murray Abraham - Scarface) and it goes through that story. Ralph Fiennes known to most as Voldemort is truly wonderful in this film really portraying the character of Gustave H. in a splendid way. It is split up into different parts but they all follow the same set of characters. The way they have done this really shows how decorative this film is, from the characters and how they speak with such sophistication to the backdrop which is all very vibrant but at the same time very regal. It is very well crafted and it feels like every aspect of this has a purpose. Credit must be given to Wes Anderson who has perfectly molded this film into a beautiful yet exciting film.  A thoroughly enjoyable watch and something that you shouldn't miss.
Pretty much what I expected from Wes Anderson. Funny, creative and with quite a few of his "regular" actors. Although I liked moonrise kingdom better it was still a great journey.

The Grande Budapest Hotel has early Oscar buzz surrounding it, does it met it's hype? My review now.

Now I'm gonna be completely honest, the plot of this movie is so random and all over the place I'm having a hard think of a plot. But what I can say is that there was something of a murder and a man being wrongly framed. A painting that costs a lot of money and it being stolen. That is literally the best way I can describe this plot.

Wes Anderson managed to create one of the weirdest, odd, quirky, and original movies I have seen in years. With a stellar cast this is a mostly enjoyable movie. I wouldn't say it's one of my favorite movies of the year but I do recommended it.

This has a stellar cast but this is one of the downfalls of this movie. There are so many actors being introduced here that it's a hard time for them to shine, although we do have some great cameos throughout which I will not spoiler. Ralph Fiennes leads the movie as M. Gustave, the owner of Budapest Hotel. He does a pretty good job from what he is given. I think that he owned every scene he was in and gave some gut busting hilarious moments throughout. 

Other actors worth mentioning is Tony Revolori as Young Zero, a lobby boy. I honestly liked him, he did a fine job and showed to be a likable presence. Adrien Brody and Willem Dafoe do good acting out of the material they are given. But I have to say it was only Ralph Fiennes and Tony Revolori who really stole the show.

Now this is one of the weirdest movies I have ever seen in my life. There are just so many random scenes of characters doing the most strange things. The screenplay while strange was excellent writing. Wes Anderson created this strange world of strange characters. I have to praise him for doing that much but I wonder, how did he manage to write this? I'm not trying to be rude at all but this kind of looks like he was either damn high. Again I'm not trying to dis him! But it did seem as if was that at times. Without a doubt one of the most original movies in years.

But this movie was pretty funny at moments. Ralph Fiennes gives some great moments throughout, he is this wise cracking, rude, self absorbed dick who doesn't care about other other than Zero. But the humor comes from the most over the top moments. I mean over the top at it's weirdest. I will not spoil anything however I will mention a sled chase sequence that just the funniest thing in the entire movie The interactions between characters were interesting to watch. They are pretty messed up or quirky people and that made it even better. 

Now visual this movie is stunning. I can see possible Oscar nominations coming it's way for art direction, production design, and even the score was great. The buildings and environment is unlike anything I have seen all year and it all does look fantastic and again, original. Everything about this movie is original, visually anyway. 

I also noticed a strange diction from Wes Anderson. The way he directed this movie and the way the picture looked. He always had a straight angle, never turned and he would hold the camera in place the entire time. Once in a while he would spin it around but he liked the use continues shots of the hallways or the characters. He even went for using quick cuts a lot. Between the continuous shots.

My biggest complaint is some of the story telling in it. There is narrating throughout but I felt it being more distracting than helping. And throughout the second act it seemed to drag on a bit. But toward the ending it picked up and become much better and more enjoyable to watch.

Overall I enjoyed the movie. It was weird without a doubt, we have a huge cast with only two of them giving really good performances. I think this will be lucky and get Oscar nominations for art direction, score, production design and maybe even screenplay for Anderson.

I give The Grand Budapest Hotel a B+.

One of, if not the best movie of 2014 thus far. Wes Anderson brings his unique storytelling perspective to the tale of a man and his lobby boy from 1923. The tale is one being told by a man who has aged considerably now and is holding on to his last connection to his lost boss/mentor and his lover (not all the same person). A bit slow at first, but once it picks up Wes Anderson's quirky directing style comes to fruition as Gustave H and his lobby boy adventure to escape from the government and retake what is rightfully his from a basic Nazi family who has tried to bury him and take what was his. This is a definite must watch.

The Grand Budapest Hotel is a typical Wes Anderson movie with his trademark characteristics his fans and film lovers adore: the deadpan delivery, consistent snappy dialogue, the always cheeky tone & the pleasant cast all were captured on a grandiose scale. While mixing old fashioned American slapstick with European settings and sensibilities, Mr. Anderson has crafted one of his most layered and best films to date (and this coming off the heels of Moonrise Kingdom). Ralph Fiennes provides such a pitch perfect delivery to old fashioned slapstick humor elevating Wes Anderson's style that you hope they form a Martin Scorsese/Leonardo DiCaprio cinematic collaborator bond.
This is the perfect movie to watch anytime. It is hilarious from beginning to end.

I probably shouldn't write a review on this, but I will anyway.  I watched this on blu ray, and after about 15 minutes started to lose interest and spent most the moving dealing ultraviolet codes on my phone with people from England.  Wes Anderson movies generally don't do anything for me(although I did like "Moonrise Kingdom").  His style is very unique, but it's not really my thing.  The parts of the movie I payed attention too, I thought were ok, but as a whole I ended up just shrugging my shoulders and going "meh" to.  The cast is terrific, and it's very offbeat, but really, you have to be in the right type of mood for it.  This isn't something you'll just throw on at 11 am on a Sunday.  If I had to bet I would say it'll get award recognition at the end of the year, and I'll probably go back and rewatch then.  Maybe I missed out on a truly great movie.  But, I doubt it.  Check it out, and let me know what you thought.  Maybe I'll revisit earlier.  Until then, just not for me.

One of the most graphic storytelling experience, camera placed squarely in front in every frame as if inspired from apple devices ads. the personality of the film is so much driven by its craft than its content. Short scenes powered with crisp editing that use the props which are extremely well thought out in details as well as narrative as if subplots in itself. It so happens that american movie makers have a more pronounced view of Europe than them themselves. A must watch for a visual treat.
