A very good typical Wes Anderson movie. If you like his style that's what you're going to get with this movie.

Ralph Fiennes plays M. Gustave the main character of the story. He's a pleasant surprise as a high class, strict, yet funny concierge. Much different from his roles I know of in Harry Potter (Voldemort) and Red Dragon (Tooth fairy).

Tony Revolori plays the point of view character, but mostly just keeps the story moving through PoV and doesn't add much more than that to the story.

Adrien Brody plays the son of a rich woman who M. Gustave curries the favor of while she stays at his hotel. He plays the evil character perfectly while adding a touch of comedy to his anger at the protagonist.

Willem DaFoe plays Brody's muscle and shows off his ability to act well even if he isn't talking.

The rest of the cast is filled by various famous actors in cameos who all add a little charm to film.

Just might be Wes Anderson's best film yet. It's frantic and relentless, moving faster seemingly than one can blink. It is a part of the film's overall charming nature though, as is the quirky humor. The entire thing gives us a creative vibe that is infectious, and what makes this one perhaps stand out from the others is that somehow, in the midst of all of that off the wall creatively it still appear grounded in something earthly and human. 

The story is a telling of an adventurous tale surrounding Zero (a lobby boy) who works for Gustave, the owner of the Grand Budapest Hotel (a famous European hotel). The story involves an art heist, but it is the backdrop of war that really centers the films sense of nostalgia and period piece. 

The visuals move back and forth from vivid and stunning to intentionally ridiculous and over the top. And while the film remains insistent on maintaing its fervent speed, it is never out of control. Anderson has made another classic, and one that can be enjoyed (no doubt) again and again.

All that said, a unique, memorable movie with seriously funny episodes and an unpredictable story nonetheless.

After watching The Grand Budapest Hotel I walked out wondering, as I often do watching a Wes Anderson film, if what I watched had any value whatsoever.  The thing is I find myself thinking about Wes Anderson films long after I've watched them, I find this is not the case with many other pieces I watch.  Overall  The Grand Budapest Hotel does not disappoint in this regard, I find my mind continually returning to its twisting labyrinthine zaniness.  

My summation of the film is simple.  It's not one of anything: its a character study, a caper, bittersweet, funny and sad.  No one would say this is a film about life, because no one's life is like the life studied, but overall the film leaves a beautiful aftertaste in your mind that makes you wonder if fantasies like this aren't just a little more real than your day to day.

I feel like this movie is one of those movies you should see twice, since the story is, in my opinion, a bit tricky to follow the first time around. The film absorbs you with its great visuals and atmosphere that the story gets kind of lost in it. 
But after viewing this movie for a second time, I really hope Wes Anderson gets another Oscar-nod for the screenplay. The movie is smart and simple when it comes to its comedy aspects. I loved some of the relationships in this movie and wished that that was the main focus of the movie.
But instead we get a story about a murder, an arrest, and a prison break. In a unique way I might add, since the movie is presented in parts. That is a very risky move because if one part seems longer than the other than that makes the movie look slow. There are five parts in this movie, and unfortunately this movie is not an exception to this rule. I felt some parts, particularly part 3, seemed to drag on for a very long time when it didn't need to be. It was just a prison break that seemed to last for an eternity. 
Regardless of the pacing, Wes Anderson sure does have plenty of style in this movie. With yet another awesome soundtrack for Alexandre Desplat and sweeping visuals, it's no wonder that Wes Anderson succeeded in the box office with this movie. I can't wait to see what visual brilliance he comes up with next.

Wes Anderson's The Grand Budapest Hotel is a quirky and stylish dark comedy.  The story follows an elusive millionaire as he recounts the extraordinary tale of how he happened to acquire the luxurious Grand Budapest Hotel.  The ensemble cast that Anderson has put together is incredible, and includes Jude Law, Ralph Fiennes, Jeff Goldblum, Saoirse Ronan, Edward Norton, and F. Murray Abraham, and their performances are especially good.  Additionally, the plot has some interesting themes (including the nature of storytelling), and the visual aesthetic is remarkably effective at setting tone and atmosphere.  Yet while the craftsmanship of The Grand Budapest Hotel is exceptional, it's a little more macabre and gratuitous than the typical Anderson film.

Wes Anderson delivers yet another film stringent to his visual style. This film (due to it's setting and time period) is especially whimsical, yet it falls flat in a spot. 

At the end of the film there is a rather crappy CGI scene, which conflicts heavily with some of the stylistic choices made earlier on. From changing the aspect ratio of the film to even putting murals as a background for the landscape shots, Anderson was obviously going for authenticity points, and unfortunately, I have to say he failed. 

Otherwise, the performances were irreverent, and Ralph Fiennes command of his role makes "The Grand Budapest Hotel" a wonderful and fresh take on Zweig's classic.

"The Grand Budapest Hotel" is indeed one of the most unique films I have ever had the pleasure to watch. This film is impossible to ignore and transcends every convention about film and spits in its collective face. Ralph Fiennes steals the show as the clever, wily concierge of the hotel, and his charm is evident the instant he graces the screen. He is an early favorite for a Best Actor nomination. This film is colorful, brilliantly scripted, and beautifully shot, something cinematography should aspire to be. The film knows it is campy and knows that its special effects are cheesy, but its sense of purposefulness and individualism pours over into the audience. This is truly a one-of-a-kind cinematic experience that is over-the-top but in a glorious and mesmerizing way. It will be impossible for this film to be ignored come December. It is an outstanding, triumphant film and one of the best to date of 2014. Its sophistication and scripting is astonishing ----------------------------------------- A-

Overall Wes Anderson does it again in the funny, witty, creative, and intelligent Grand Budapest Hotel.

It is hard to categorize this movie in a genre, because it is so unique in that it is many things at one time. Mostly, this is a wildly unpredictable adventure. There are a few action sequences, yet they show a unique solemn restraint that deliberately reduces them to whimsical events in a plot, rather than raw excitement. Often it is sentimental or reflective with themes of old age, friendship, and young love. Thankfully, the substantive emotion never pulls the mood down. It has wonderfully intriguing characters and an amazing cast to bring to personality and life to them. There are even somewhat mysterious elements to the story to keep you guessing and a few mildly humorous moments. It really defies categorization, but it certainly bears the stamp of a Wes Anderson movie. This is by far my favorite Wes Anderson effort. His pretentious subdued monotone dullness normally rubs me the wrong way. The difference here from his other films is in the delightfully spontaneous and eventful story that has colorful characters with definitive personality. Ralph Fines, in particular, makes an unforgettable with great presence that defines the movie. He is the main character, but his story comes through the perspective of his protégé. The story moves quickly and smoothly and the flashback conversational narration has a pleasant storytelling quality. It is many things, but Anderson brings it all together in one clear and incredibly fun adventure.

I mean, if you've seen his other films, you can associate all of these characters with characters from his other works.  There's an oddness that is purely Anderson's schtick that I've never seen anyone replicate.  Perhaps I would esteem this one more had I seen it before some of his other films.  Again, it's not bad. Good Film! In this film, director Wes Anderson creates his own universe, full of colourful characters, old-world charm and witty one-liners. The nice thing about creating your own universe is that you can make it look perfect. Every shot, every little detail and every set is flawless. Ralph Fiennes steals the show as the sophisticated Gustave H., who never despairs, even in the most unfavourable circumstances. He is supported by a large number of star actors, who are sometimes almost unrecognizable. Because of the amount of support actors, some of them are a bit underused. Tilda Swinton gets rather little screen time, as does Harvey Keitel. The film moves forward at a breakneck speed. You have to be very alert in order not to miss something. The plot is not always very easy to follow, and the dialogue is fast. And there are the great camera angles and the wonderful detailed sets to pay attention to. I think by seeing the film a second time you can discover lots of things you didn't notice the first time. 

GRAND BUDAPEST HOTEL recounts the adventures of Gustave H, a legendary concierge at a famous European hotel between the wars, and Zero Moustafa, the lobby boy who becomes his most trusted friend. The story involves the theft and recovery of a priceless Renaissance painting and the battle for an enormous family fortune -- all against the back-drop of a suddenly and dramatically changing Continent.

Only Wes Anderson can come with a film this unique in tone and this visually eccentric.  That is a good thing, since so many films today do not have the stamp on the director on them.  They could be made by anyone and produce the same result.  Not true of Anderson.  He shows off his own personality in his films.

Ralph Fiennes is M. Gustave.  He is a famous concierge at one of Europes most picturesque hotels.  When the wealthy Madame D. passes away, she wills her most prized possession, a painting to Gustave.  Her son, Dmitri(Adrien Brody) refuses the gift and Gustave and his Lobby Boy, Zero, steal the painting.

Dmitri and his thugs chase the pair across the continent.  Things get more complicated when a second will surfaces.

Quirky, but in a good way.  It is highly entertaininga nd features a host of solid actors and actresses, such as: Edward Norton, Bill Murray, Harvey Keitel, Jude Law, Tilda Swinton, Willem Dafoe, Jeff Goldblum, and F. Murray Abraham.

Extremely stylish both in terms of visual aesthetic and production values , Wes Anderson's unique piece is one of those few films in modern cinema which keeps your faith in movie art. This is a film filled with old school style , both in front of the camera and behind it. The film swells in its beautiful setting of the 30s to 80s - all beautifully portrayed by the rich production design and the wonderful performance to go with that. Ralph Fiennes takes this beautiful layered script filled with comedy and subtle drama and takes it to a new level with a brilliant performance - certainly the best of the year so far. It is expertly written , stylized by the beautiful and unique elements of cinematography to go with it . The camera was given a character - it's a very unique style of shooting the film with static cameras throughout making the center of the screen as the pivot. The style runs throughout the different settings in the entire length of the film. Another notable piece was the excellent use of changing aspect ratios to state the setting of the story. The story itself , being a short journey of the lead character - wonderfully narrated  by F Murray Abraham. The cast was brilliant , eccentric and the performance came across the screen. Technically the movie is a brilliant piece of art. If i am to draw any straws i would like to mention the slightly unbelievable nature of the miniatures or models used in this picture . But then again that might be for any reason or limitations. However that's a point to be noted as some of the very wide shots do dwell in the realm of uncertainty. The score is wonderfully written , original yet dwells on the period nature of the story. Overall , this was a nice piece of art with a comedic performance with underlying very strong and mature emotional resonance and the credit for that must go to both the script and the actors. Although it might be one of those films ignored by many movie goers - but to those that views it this will be a movie which is more like a portrait . "The Grand Budapest" hotel is a sophisticated achievement

Pretentious is the best word to describe this superficially witty trifle of a film, which is watchable only for the occasional richness and creativity of its cinematography. All the slavering critical praise here is evidence of how divorced from authentic standards the majority of our current review class has become.  Wes Anderson seems to be full of himself and enamored of deadpan humor and the use of a jarring vulgarity in the midst of otherwise high-brow dialogue, as if that's just so damn funny no matter how many times we hear it.  I guess he was inspired by Monty Python in his younger days.  But inspired is not what this film should be called.  Cheeky and simple-minded, with no real substance to the story, this whimsical waste of good cash proves once again that too many critics are won over by self-important directors whose films have no real gravity, which even good humor must have.

Rather than create characters out of thin air, you let the characters reach out to you.  It's as if the vast array of characters in "The Grand Budapest Hotel" reached out to Wes Anderson and his colorful and quirky universe.  It shows that Wes Anderson continues to mature as a wonderful and emotionally-resonant storyteller.  He is exercising broader appeal, no longer accessing a niche audience which seemed to characterize his earlier, and also quite enjoyable, artistic efforts, pre-"Fantastic Mr. Fox".

If you've followed my reviews, then you've come to be aware of my problems with Wes Anderson's particular brand of film-making.  You will never read, in any of my reviews of his films, that I think he makes bad films.  If I ever say that, it's because I think a particular film of his is bad and not because he's a terrible filmmaker.  That would be a fallacy.  The problem I have is how often he puts he lets his idiosyncratic touches, whether it be shooting techniques, writing characters, how he frames shots, etc, get in the way of effective storytelling.  Moonrise Kingdom, his last film, and my least favorite of his films, is a perfect example of this.  I think that film had a chance to tell a good story with emotional depth and poignancy, but all that was lost in the midst of all the quirkiness.  It's the same thing that happened to Fantastic Mr. Fox.  He let his quirks get in the way of a good story.  While I certainly gave this film the same rating as Moonrise Kingdom and Fantastic Mr. Fox, I have no problem in admitting that The Grand Budapest Hotel is Wes Anderson's best film in 13 years.  Or, for those of you not aware, when The Royal Tenenbaums was released.  That movie is, undoubtedly, his masterpiece.  I'm STILL only missing Rushmore, I NEED to watch that.  This isn't a great film, but it's very, very, very good  While it's very obvious that this is a Wes Anderson film, fans of his will quickly pick up on that, I think this is one of the few movies that, while quirky, doesn't become overbearing to the point that it makes the rest of the film tedious to watch.  There's actually a good little story here.  Well let me clarify that, the whole story about Gustave being framed for murder and his and Zero's attempts to exonerate him is actually a bit of a mess to follow at times.  I just think that it's needlessly expansive, almost as if designed by Wes Anderson to get some of the people he enjoys collaborating with a paycheck.  There's nothing wrong with that, but if the story was a little more stripped back, it probably would've been better.  But there are characters that don't really need to be here and all they do is help clog up the drain, so to speak.  Of course I say that, but at least even the smallest of characters gets something important to do.  It might not be of the utmost important to the main story, but they get something to do and that's what matters.  Ultimately though, while the story is certainly entertaining, and probably Anderson's broadest, what really holds the film together is Zero's relationship with Gustave and how that develops throughout the film.  It's clear that Gustave's personality, much like is mentioned in the film, is just an illusion.  It's clear that there was something in his past, something tragic, that has made him the way he is.  In many ways, he is incredibly overprotective of Zero and, later, by extension, Agatha.  He deeply cares for Zero and comes to consider him a good friend.  That part of the film I very much enjoyed, the chemistry between Ralph Fiennes and Tony Revolori is excellent.  There's also the fact that the story is set against the backdrop of the impending war, clearly inspired by World War 2.  Because of that, in spite of all the whimsy and fun moments the film provides, there's this air of impending doom.  Like something is bad is going to happen that is, invariably, going to change everything.  Nothing will ever be the same again after the war hit Zubrowka.  I think that underlying core to the film is, leaps and bounds, better than the main story itself.  Thinking about whatever happened in the past that made Gustave into the insecure and vain person he is, much like the women he romances, and that sense of impending doom, that the great war will destroy everything in its path.  How the now much older Zero chooses to keep the hotel running, because it's one of the few places where he was truly happy.  Those are the real highlights of the film to me.  Visually, this film is very obviously a Wes Anderson film, its cinematography is excellent.  The costume design is very bright and colorful, almost decorative in a sense, as if you're watching a movie painting.  I will say that the film is meticulously crafted.  Not that his other films weren't, but it's more obvious here.  And it's also clear that the film was inspired by some slapstick classics.  To Anderson's credit, it doesn't come across as theft as much as paying tribute, while at the same time adding his own idiosyncratic touch to those classics.  The cast is top-notch, Ralph Fiennes absolutely kills it here with his performance, man has great comedic timing.  The film has such a large cast that, unfortunately, nobody stands out as much as Ralph Fiennes, and Tony Revolori himself, but everyone gets a little color.  There's no character here that isn't interesting and, again, that's a credit to Anderson's eye for eccentric characterization.  Like I said, the story is definitely a bit of a mess, but I very much enjoyed this movie.  It's Wes Anderson and his fans will approve.  The unconverted, however, will find nothing to win them over.  While I think this is his best film in 13 years, even I didn't think it was great.  I don't think that, miraculously, this film would make me not feel skeptical when going into Anderson's next project.  I always know he can just revert to his olden ways and just do quirky for the fuck of it with no regards to story.  Still, this is a very good movie.  Can't exactly recommend it however, as it entirely depends on how you view Wes Anderson's style.

The story revolves around the incredible adventures of womanizer Gustave H, a legendary concierge at the famous Grand Budapest Hotel and Zero Moustafa, the lobby boy who becomes his most trusted friend. Review:
What a brilliant movie from Wes Anderson. The storyline goes down so many different avenues which keeps the movie interesting throughout. The cast was amazing and Ralph Fiennes was brilliant as the lead. Like many other Wes Anderson movies, the film is very original, with a punchy script that is funny throughout. The sets were amazing, along with the different costumes and the whole look of the strange and mysterious hotel. It's one of those movies were you will see something new every time that you watch it because of the attention to detail and the many different characters who have there own individual backgrounds. In all, it's a movie not to miss, but you do have to have a certain sense of humour to enjoy it. Brilliant!

Round-Up:
This role was definitely made for Ralph Fiennes, who played his part extremely well. The chemistry between him and his bellboy was great and I liked the way that he dealt with Tilda Swinton at the beginning. The cast must have been a joy to work with because there are so many big names who bring there own unique styles to this masterpiece. I've always been a fan of Wes Anderson's movies, but this one is close to his best work. Anyway, it's definitely worth a watch if you want to see something original and extremely witty.

Wes Anderson is a highly celebrated director for our time but not one I am too familiar with.
The only previous works of his that I have seen are Moonrise Kingdom and The Royal Tenanbaums. Both of which I enjoyed for their colourful visuals and hilarious writing.
I am pleased to say that Anderson does it again (and perfectly) with Grand Budapest.  The cast that he managed to assemble for this is filled with his usual and a number of others that is too long to list off.
To explain the plot of GBH is a hard thing to do but to sum it up it's about a cast of ridiculous characters all connected to this one hotel and the story that unfolds is part fairy tale, part cartoon, part stage play and part novel.

It has a very distinct and fast paced style that benefits from the well-timed humour and sometimes shocking violence.

The writing is something I can't praise enough.  Written by Wes Anderson himself, he has a full-realized vision for each character and you really feel the heart behind each one (except the ones that are heartless i.e. Willem Dafoe and Adrien Brody).

The bright colours and beautiful snowy landscapes are absolutely wonderful to look at and fully take in.  Snow-covered streets and mountaintops are shown throughout the movie and give you a sense of the fantastical place where this hotel is based.  Also adding to that fact is the amazing set design.  The pink walls, the fancy chandeliers and beautiful artwork placed throughout the lavish Budapest hotel tell you whom the place was meant for.

I've noticed that because of how different and original Anderson's movies tend to be, he gets these actors that have seem to have all but disappeared.  And not only does he manage to get them on board, but also to get some of their best work out of them.

Bill Murray and Edward Norton are prime examples of this.  Completely nailing their roles and comedic timing.  It was also nice to see Harvey Keitel back as a crazy buffed out prisoner who helps Ralph Fiennes character break out.

Adrien Brody and Willem Dafoe as the nefarious and twisted Desgoffe-und-Taxis (most hilarious last name ever) contributed some of the most hilarious and violent scenes of the film.

The Grand Budapest Hotel is one of the most violent, funniest and heartfelt comedies I have ever seen and the characters and setting can never be stripped from memory.
I continue to have almost no appreciation Wes Anderson films.

If you were to walk blind folded into a movie, you'd only need 5 seconds to recognize you are watching a Wes Anderson film. His quirky sense of humor and stylized films are so unique that he manages to draw us in to this colorful world effortlessly. The Grand Budapest Hotel is no exception, and once again Anderson introduces us to a quirky setting full of dysfunctional yet amusing characters. In my opinion there was no better setting for an Anderson film than a fictional country in Eastern Europe like the one in The Grand Budapest Hotel where these gigantic and beautiful ancient castles fit his style perfectly. At times his films feel like you are turning the page of an illustrated book from one scene to the next and that is what is so unique about his style. I am a huge fan of his films and wasn't disappointed with his latest effort although I wouldn't consider it amongst his best work (Rushmore, The Royal Tenenbaums, and Moonrise Kingdom are my favorites). I do acknowledge however that his films tend to grow on me upon rewatches so it may manage to make it near the top of my list in the future. Once again watching an Anderson film proved to be a wonderful and unique experience, and I laughed hard during many scenes. Anderson never seems to lose his touch as there are several memorable moments throughout the film.

No one can deny Wes Anderson's creativity and it is just a pleasure to experience what his quirky mind is going to come up with next. The dialogue is brilliant once again and several characters stand out. Ralph Fiennes in the lead role as the hotel concierge is brilliant as is his apprentice, Tony Revolori. The two have great chemistry together as Fiennes' character sort of becomes the parent figure of the young lobby boy, which Anderson always loves to explore in his films. The epic cast was brilliant as well, and it was good to see Anderson's frequent collaborators on screen together once again. They may not have much screen time, but Anderson fans will appreciate every second they are on screen (Bill Murray, Jason Schwartzman, Owen Wilson, and Tilda Swinton). The highlight of the film for me were the spectacular and hilarious chase scenes through the gorgeous Alps background and Willem Dafoe's comedic performance. The way Anderson edited those scenes was extremely funny as well. I really liked the quirky soundtrack  which just added to my overall enjoyment of the film. I only wish the film would've explored the romantic relationship between Tony Revolori and Saoirse Ronan a bit more and that it wouldn't have concluded in such an open ended way. It was still a lot of fun!

A lovely screwball comedy by director Wes Anderson.

Employing a stellar line up including lead Ralph Fiennes and Murray Brahsm, Jude Law, Adrien Bhuzrody, Edward Norton, Jeff Goldblum and Tilda Swinton this quirky, witty caper centres around a camp concierge of a famous European hotel with a taste for wealthy OAPs, his relationship with a lobby boy who becomes his trusted friend and a priceless Renaissance painting that he's accused of stealing by the family one of his former lovers. 

As usual with Wes Anderson's films it looks absolutely beautiful, it's all about colour and composition and how everything looks. But there's also a lot of great comedy.

If you found Wes Anderson's previous films pretentious, you'll find this a lot more accessible. Arguably his best film to date. If you missed it, it's out now available on DVD, BluRay and to download. Buy it!

M. Gustave: You see, there are still faint glimmers of civilization left in this barbaric slaughterhouse that was once known as humanity. Indeed that's what we provide in our own modest, humble, insignificant... oh, fuck it.

Wes Anderson es un director que tiende a adoptar la misma estética en todas las películas que dirige, y mientras son hermosas visualmente, los personajes y sus historias no me conmueven y en The Grand Budapest Hotel es la primera película después de The Royal Tenenbaums donde los personajes tienen la misma fuerza que las imágenes. 

Como siempre, esta película reúne a un elenco genial de actores, que se destacan en sus respectivos papeles, especialmente Ralph Fiennes como Gustave H, el encargado del hotel, donde es interpretado con el humor característico de Anderson, pero la actuación de Fiennes logra darle una dimensión que sobrepasa cualquier expectativa. 

La historia de The Grand Budapest Hotel tiene un gran peso. Habla acerca de la amistad entre Gustave H y el botones del hotel Zero. Sin importar las diferencias entre los dos encuentran un medio donde les permite aceptarse entre ellos, y se embarcan en aventuras emocionantes. Ese es otro aspecto de la película que me sorprendió, el suspenso. Hay escenas donde realmente te preguntas como saldrán de esa situación, por ejemplo durante la fuga de la cárcel, la cual estuvo ejecutada perfectamente, y si no tuviera esa estética, hubiera dudado si realmente es una película dirigida por este director, y me alegra cuestionármelo porque significa que está tomando riesgos e intentando cosas distintas en sus películas. También la escena del monasterio, que mezcla el humor con la tragedia excelentemente. En realidad, casi todas las escenas de esta película son memorables, y tienen algo especial y claro que como siempre la estética juega un papel importante, y nunca deja de impresionarme la perfección con la cual es logrado, sobretodo la simetría y la paleta de colores. 

The Grand Budapest Hotel es luego de The Royal Tenenbaums de mis favoritas por Wes Anderson. A pesar de que mantiene su estética usual, hizo algo distinto y emocionante, y espero que siga desarrollando esa nueva faceta en su dirección.

The Grand Budapest Hotel is one of the most masterfully made movies I have ever seen. Not because of it's special effects (which are perhaps corny at times, whether purposefully or not) or even because of it's remarkable cast featuring Wes Anderson's go-to talents. It's the depth of the characters, and the impressive comedic performance of Ralph Fiennes, who previously has been the portrayer of epitomes of villains, that truly impresses. I would recommend this movie to anyone who wishes to follow a moderately complicated humorous plot set in an impressively realistic made-up Eastern European country.

This is my first Wes Anderson film. It will not be my last. The Grand Budapest Hotel is endearing, fun, quirky, and bold. The dialogue is snappy, the characters felt alive. But, the best part of this film was the director. I've heard of Wes Anderson's style, quirky and fun and I've seen some clips from his movies. But, I've never sat through a full viewing of any of his films. And goddamn it I wish I had. The cinematography is amazing and the way it was directed was truly a wonder to behold. I even found that some scenes looked like art, literally, looked like a painting that was alive. It was so beautiful to witness what a director could do when they put their heart and their mind into their project. Wes Anderson did an excellent job with this film which is, literally, a piece of art.

The plot is quite simple for a movie as layered as its famous Mendl's cakes (by the way *SPOILER ALERT*). It's basically about a well-known concierge (played by Ralph Fiennes) whom steals a painting (that was his according to a piece of the will, but the piece of the will was burnt albeit there was a second copy that no one knew about until the near-to-end of the film) and he is accompanied by a lobby boy who is also his protégé and the one to own the Grand Budapest Hotel later on. So, craziness, hilarity, wackiness, quirkiness, randomness, everything maniacal, just what you'd expect from Wes Anderson, ensues. The reason it's layered is because of just that, a lot of things happen in this not too long of a runtime for a film and it feels loaded, but balanced at the same time. It's like Anderson knew exactly how much to put in. And the performances were spectacular. Everyone had a role to play and they all did it wonderfully with just as much of an amount of quirkiness added to each and every one of the characters. Even the actual hotel had, what felt like, a soul. Everything felt so alive, the colors of each shot jumped out at you, but it had enough restraint to not make you feel burdened by it. You can see how meticulously crafted this film was.

The performances were spectacular. Everyone had a role to fill and they all did it exceedingly well. But, the breakout from this, the one who stole each and every scene was no other than Ralph. If there is a definition of underrated, it's definitely Ralph Fiennes. At the beginning of the film when I first saw his face I couldn't even remember his real name. He stole the show and his character was extremely likeable. Another thing that worked well was the cameos and the supporting actors. Adrian Brody was a great bad guy and so was Willem. Bill Murray was charming, and so was Jeff Goldblum. I actually felt genuinely bad when Jeff died, but the way it was shot made me laugh, which it was supposed to, because a steel door tore all four fingers off his hand, but they popped off and it reminded me of cartoons I would watch as a little kid and it was meant to be taken lightly. And I guess that's the point the film is trying to make.

It's a serious world out there. And I mean it can get dark and gloomy as shown in the film (through the wars, and the train stops). Everything can get quite sad and messed up. But, the film plays it off as if it was to be taken lightly. I feel that Anderson made it that way to deliberately say, "Life is serious, and things may get taken away from you, loved ones will die, but there is always humanity, there is always someone there that can wipe that all away when it seemingly encroaches in from all around you." This is what the film was about. It wasn't supposed to be taken seriously, but it was supposed to be emotional. And that's why when it was ending and it showed Zero (the lobby boy) at his later years as the owner, explaining to the author what the hotel was like and how it was now. It looked like it was all in ruin, in shambles, even the concierge wasn't there which led to Zero having to get his own key to his own room. The soul of the Grand Budapest Hotel suddenly felt not so grand. It felt dead, and it was no longer alive like it used to be. But when Zero stepped in the elevator and when the author said good-bye, Zero smiled as the doors closed.

And that's when I began feeling tears.

This sick world that has a sort of beauty to it is dying, but that doesn't stop us. We still keep going. We still keep moving. And it's our memories, or past experiences, our very lives that carry us on. And even when the very thing he grew up in, that helped him when he was down, that was in ruins and that was dying, even if the hotel was all that at the present, Zero still didn't care. He was able to look past all the old, all the ruin, all the emptiness, and he felt more alive than ever because he knew what the place used to be like. And he still kept it in his heart what it was. Wes Anderson basically flipped off all the evil that can be found in the world and told it all to go fuck itself because he doesn't take it seriously. This is his personal message, this is his film. This is what he wanted to say through the characters, the story, the acting, the quirkiness, the randomness, the war, the assholes, everything. This is what he thinks and I can't help but admire the man for that. That's how we should all truly live and that's how Zero and Gustave lived. That is the story of the Grand Budapest Hotel.

Throughout the film I thought of it as just a fun experience so I wanted to give it an 8/10, but when the end came and I saw what had happened it bumped it up a point. But...then I started writing this review and I thought back on the film. Sure it was fun and of course it has flaws, every film has flaws, but the moral/point/message of the film stands up tall in my eyes. The film knows it has flaws, but it doesn't take anything seriously and yet it still is moving enough to make me get teary eyed. This is a work of art. It didn't need something pretentious to get its message across; it just needed a competent director that actually loves what he does. This film is what all directors need to strive for nowadays. Because all I see are directors who just don't give a fuck and want money, but this one actually cared. And it made me care. 

And so with that I will give this film the honor of being my first RT rating of...

10/10

I love movies. Anyone who knows me knows that fact. I went to school for photography/film analysis many years ago so I consider it a rare treat when a film grabs hold of me in so many ways that I can't even describe. The film critic inside me just can't wait to share with you the amazing-ness that some filmmakers imbibe their creations with, and THIS is one of those movies. This is one of the reasons I fell in love with film in the 1st place and why I write these reviews (that I hope) you will read on my Facebook page.
Let me 1st say that I've always admired director Wes Anderson's work, but I've always thought that he's been a little overrated. Yeah I enjoyed 'Rushmore', 'The Royal Tanenbaums', and most recently 'Moonrise Kingdom', but I often felt that his movies were best viewed in a museum, or from under a glass case. His films often struck me as a bit pretentious and a bit too smart for their own good.
But I have since changed my mind. And it is because of 'The Grand Budapest Hotel'. The film is so lovingly made, the cinematography is so fantastic, the music so infectious, the acting across the board so fun to watch that I absolutely will put Wes Anderson's name on the short list of best American filmmakers that are working right now.
Here's the plot synopsis:"THE GRAND BUDAPEST HOTEL recounts the adventures of Gustave H, a legendary concierge at a famous European hotel between the wars, and Zero Moustafa, the lobby boy who becomes his most trusted friend. The story involves the theft and recovery of a priceless Renaissance painting and the battle for an enormous family fortune -- all against the back-drop of a suddenly and dramatically changing Continent". (courtesy of Fox Searchlight)
Now that that's out of the way, I can tell you that you probably won't have a more fun time watching a movie this year. It's so vibrant and full of life, it kind of reminds me of an old Charlie Chaplin or Marx Bros film (except in glorious color) where something crazy is happening in EVERY frame. I wanted to pause this movie so many times just to take it all in. 
We are now in July, and so the year is more than half over. This is MY PICK for Best Picture of the year (so far). I doubt there's anything that will be able to top it, but we'll see. It's truly a masterpiece. My HIGHEST of the HIGHEST recommendation! As close to perfect as a movie can get. :) :) :)

This is Wes Anderson's best film in many regards: the story actually grabs me, the characters' quirkiness is pulled back a bit to the point that they're almost relatable, and none of the characters are blatantly just an embodiment of Anderson's own self, childhood, and problems. All that said, I still am not a fan of Anderson's style. Although this was a very potentially good story, the character quirks and the visual surrealism (although gorgeous) just makes the whole experience a little more of a story I listen to rather than an experience I get immersed in and relate to.

I've never been a big Wes Anderson fan, so I was quite surprised by how much I enjoyed The Grand Budapest Hotel.  All of Anderson's key filmmaking trademarks are out in full force here (gorgeous cinematography, stylized editing, over-the-top characters), but all set within a classic screwball comedy.  Ralph Fiennes carries the movie extremely well, proving himself to be a wonderfully eccentric straight man with perfect comedic timing.  He's surrounded by a great supporting cast of bizarre characters who keep the film, and the laughs, moving along nicely.  My only major criticism was the third act, which ends with a fizzle instead of a bang.  I'm sure Anderson's fans already love this movie, but those who aren't might actually find a lot to enjoy here.

Wes Anderson has been steadfastly honing his finesse since the outset of his career starting from BOTTLE ROCKET (1996) when he was only 27, from then, this wunderkind's filmography has flourished healthily, presently he is among the most successful auteur in US indie ground and internationally his fame also balloons with his audience, his eighth feature THE GRAND BUDAPEST HOTEL, this year Berlin International Film Festival's opening film (and Grand Jury Prize winner) and a genuine box-office triumph, indicates he is not slowing down in any aspect.

Every so often we are treated to a brand new film from Director Wes Anderson. He's that rare gem of a filmmaker whose grasp on a singular vision seems not to allow for a dip in quality. He's truly in a league; a world of his own and his cinematic output needs to be judged accordingly. 2014 is another year, and as predictable as that is, equally predictable is "The Grand Budapest Hotel" being another great Wes Anderson picture. If it's not his best, it is arguably his most ambitious on a narrative level, and unarguably on a visual one. The production design is gorgeous, the writing and humor work in quirky tandem, and Ralph Fienne's terrific work as the headlining Gustave H. highlights one of Anderson's most memorable, strange, and strangely likable creations.

Sure it's a movie where the main focus is on Ralph Fiennes and his lobby boy played terrifically by an unknown, but there's a hint of a few regulars Anderson has used before and more than just a cameo from many others to really keep the story interesting.  Eccentric and conspicuous all the same, the Grand Budapest seemed like a wonderful fairytale for a fairytale.

The Grand Budapest Hotel (2014) - 8

The setting jumps between four distinct periods; the most interesting to us is the most remote, in 1932. Eccentric Gustave H, prominent concierge at the Grand Budapest Hotel, and his newly employed lobby boy Zero Moustafa live the end of the hotel's golden age as the war approaches the state of Zubrowka. Both will get themselves in serious trouble after the mysterious death of Céline, one of the numerous love aberrations of Gustave. Among her voluminous heritage lies a valuable painting that was willed to Gustave--blasphemy for her family who won't take half-measures to reclaim what should be rightfully theirs. Gustave and Zero will jump on a risky and whimsical adventure until the conflict of interests is settled for the best and the worst. I think it's safe to describe this as the darkest Wes Anderson movie, darkly fun that is. Both for the story and the characters, especially the brutal cold-blooded killer J. G. Jopling, who has become one of my favorites in Wes filmography. Willem Dafoe can really put together a convincing killer act. This playfully eccentric, witty and darkly fun movie is among Wes' most expressive works, in my opinion. The Grand Budapest Hotel abounds with memorable scenes, dark humor and the deviant Gustave H might very well be the most iconic character in this mannerist universe, great acting from Ralph Fiennes. Steve Zissou is still my favorite goon, though. The Grand Budapest Hotel shows greater maturity and assertiveness from Wes, who has been granted with more sophisticated technical wizardry and casting quality in his latter works.

However, I'm left with a faint feeling that Wes may have reached the creative limits of his cinematic artifice. In the beginning, I was intrigued by the possibility that the four distinct settings and narrators could bring something new and substantial to the table, but that doesn't seem to be the case in my perception. Looking back, it almost seems like a simple technical gimmick to persuade the viewer that the movie holds more substance than it actually does. This is still the basic formula used in all Wes' movies, but this time enriched with a strong wistful flavor arising from the fact that the whole adventure is nothing more than the cherished memory of what was live and loved by Zero Moustafa--only this would justify a space-time transition, and only one would be enough. What's the point of four transitions? It seems redundant to me. The whole story is apparently read on the present by the girl in the a cemetery sitting just beside the grave of the book's author, but we barely become aware of it. Other than its darkly comical side, this could enhance even more the notion of distant or dreamlike past, in which case more development in the "sober" present would be desirable. Fortunately this wasn't a distraction per se; just a personal remark to explain my mixed feelings about the four settings and the ending. I found the whole movie very engrossing and entertaining; Wes is an expert of mood manipulation. I am very curious to see what he will do next. The Grand Budapest Hotel is Wes' sharpest mannerism. Highly recommended!

"There are still faint glimmers of civilization left in this barbaric slaughterhouse that was once known as humanity"

The Wes Anderson nerd inside me just couldn't help but adore his latest venture into the obscure, yet fun world of The Grand Budapest Hotel.

In the most lavish, posh hotel in Zubrowska (a cleverly named fake country), the head concierge M. Gustave H. (Ralph Fiennes) is a well-revered individual, even if he is a massive womanizer, but for senior citizens and not young chicks like most playboys are. Anyways, one of his "wooed blondes" Madame Céline Villeneuve Desgoffe und Taxis, or just Madame D (Tilda Swinton) gets murdered and leaves the hilariously silly painting Boy with Apple to Gustave in her will, and at the funeral, D's son Dmitri (Adrien Brody) pins Gustave as the prime suspect. Now Gustave and his recently hired lobby boy Zero (Tony Revolori) must set out to prove is innocence, with comic mayhem ensuing at every turn.

This story within a story within a story, cleverly composed by Anderson and story writer Hugo Guinness, is just a delicious spinning yarn. It could've been very easy to make a story like this uninteresting and boring, but Anderson populates the candy-colored world (marvelously put together by production designer Adam Stackhousen) with some pretty interesting and memorable characters, including a lovable rogue in M. Gustave H., played exquisitely by Ralph Fiennes. Included is a wonderful who's who cast ensemble that ranked amongst the very best I've seen in a Wes Anderson film, all of whom pull of great jobs even if they are only onscreen for but a few minutes. Noticeable standouts include Adrien Brody as the potty-mouthed, revenge-filled son of Madame D, and Willem Dafoe as J.G. Jopling, my favourite character, as Dmitri's emotionless assassin.

As huge of a Wes Anderson nerd I am, it's debatable as to whether or not this is his greatest film to date, but I think it is the most "Anderson-y" of the films he's done. This is in every way his film and his style. I love how no other filmmaker has the balls to make films like this, and for his individuality in a world where there are remakes and sequels that plague theatres is always welcomed. I go into further detail in my Moonrise Kingdom review, and while he does turn some off just by how "weird" he is, I have a strong feeling that homey knows exactly what he's doing.

Like the opening quote details, which is in my mind more true today than it ever has, and the story, about the humor and heartbreak of relationships is brilliantly weaved in Anderson's glorious script. The humorous moments gave me frequent chuckles, from the subtle to the macabre, but it also provides an interestingly thoughtful take on how friendships work. Gustave's deliciously prickish attitude coupled with Zero's quiet innocence quite literally makes this film, if you ask me. For as so much visual splendor is in hotel, and how much charm is in the concierge, I felt that the flick has a wonderful beating heart underneath all that deliciousness.

While not as funny as Fantastic Mr. Fox, or as magical as Moonrise Kingdom (I actually still say that Moonrise is the better feature), The Grand Budapest Hotel shines both as a humorous, candy-coated period piece but also as a thoughtful work on relationships. M. Gustave H. and his little lobby boy Zero are just as entertaining now, as they undoubtedly will be during repeated viewings, and if you are as big of a Wes Anderson fan as I am, then be sure to check into this hotel whenever you get the opportunity.

***1/2 out of ****
FINAL VERDICT: 88%

Anderson's stylistic approach makes light of and fantasizes often dreary, sophisticated themes creating adult fairytales. The Grand Budapest Hotel is no exception and compartmentalizes a thrilling wondrous adventure into a world and time that's seemingly impossible of such things.

What sticks out in this film is not only how his focus on quirky storytelling juxtaposes many of the darker occurrences of Gustave's tale, but also how it was acknowledged from Zero's recollection as a fantasy. That the beauty, charm, and humor that we were all enjoying was simply in a man... too "civil" for this world.

It's an interesting character study of illusion and one's ability to create a veil of existence that's even contagious to those around him. The idealized romance between Zero and Agatha, successful escape from prison, reclamation of his innocence and rise to fortune was all just so slightly mired with murder, sacrifice, and untimely deaths all around. It's like a careful dance between a dream and actuality.

I recall 2012's "Life of Pi", where I feel that movie failed this succeeded by utilizing a comedic undertone to capture the viewer's imagination before deconstructing it's beauty with harsh realities. There's an endless supply of offbeat laughs and thrills before we're brought to a cathartic conclusion.

After Moonrise Kingdom disappointed me a bit I'm relieved to say The Grand Budapest Hotel is one of Anderson's best and fans of his work will most definitely enjoy it. Those who aren't? Just the same.

This British-German co-production financed by German financial companies and film funding organizations, was filmed entirely on location in Germany. It was a crazy, sweet inspirational story of Monsieur Gustave H. (Ralph Fiennes) and  Zero Moustafa (Tony Revolori), a concierge and a lobby boy of the Grand Budapest Hotel who forged an unusual and unforgettable partnership after a rich woman, a client of the hotel, suddenly dies.

Adorable stylish movie, with rapid-fire delivery script filled with dry wit and cheerful profanity will never abandon you... it will keep taking you further and further on its magical journey of imaginary Alpine life during the war! Perfect acting, close to perfect screenplay and very solid directing will give you pure enjoyment, fun and depth which will slowly grow on you while watching, and you will become aware of it just at the end. Don't miss it!

Wes Anderson's latest movie, The Grand Budapest Hotel, may be the writer/director's best work to date. His normal brilliance is apparent through the duration of the dramatic comedy, making for 99 minutes of cinematic genius.

Riveting performances by Ralph Fiennes as the esteemed and unquestionably refined, concierge Gustave H, paired with his eager to learn sidekick, lobby boy Zero Moustafa (Tony Revolori), are the steam that keeps this comedy/drama engine running.

The tale of how the famed Grand Budapest hotel fell into the hands of a refugee lobby boy (Zero Mustafa) plays out marvelously. The adventure the two embark on is as grandiose as it is captivating. Wes Anderson's mind creates a universe that is fun and goofy, with dashes of explicit, which provides sheer entertainment value throughout this movie.

The story is quickly teased by The Author as an old man (Tom Wilkinson - present day). Wilkinson grips your attention from the start, before jumping to an earlier time, where The Author as a young man (Jude Law), encounters the older Zero Moustafa, further teasing the story's true inception. By the time the story finds its footing, Wes Anderson has you completely enthralled, following Fiennes and his protege Zero on this creative caper.

It doesn't take long for the ride to begin after an organic meeting between the Author and enigmatic Grand Budapest owner, Zero Moustafa takes place. Shortly after, a dinner is agreed upon so the mysterious owner, who resides in the building in a room the size of a storage closet, can share his remarkable tale to the curious Author. The story then jumps to an even earlier time where the legendary fable of concierge and lobby boy truly begins.

Gustave's charm matches the quality of the affluent company he keeps down to the Lair de Panache he is seldom without. The systematic and overly charismatic concierge, is the toast of the Grand Budapest as well as the mastermind behind its inner workings. His calculated approach is shared with lobby boy Zero, who begins as pupil to the meticulous concierge, before forming a brother-like bond with his eccentric teacher.
Gustave H's close nit connectedness to every minute detail of the Grand Budapest, enables him to wine and bed some of its wealthier inhabitants, while building invaluable relationships. Gustave's brashness is wildly comedic, making it acceptable and endearing to the characters in the story and audience alike.

The concierge's curious relationship with one hotel guest in particular, Madame Céline Villeneuve Desgoffe-und-Taxis (Tilda Swinton), is the catalyst behind Gustave's imprisonment. His relationship with the countess is inextricably linked to his fate throughout the film. Even in prison, Gustave embraces his fate with charm and grace, his charisma never fleeting.
After Gustave is framed for murder the story takes an unexpected turn, the twists and turns along the way to proving his innocence set up entertaining challenge after challenge, offering intrigue throughout the film as they work to prove Gustave's innocence.

As with most Wes Anderson pictures, there are masterfully crafted characters, whose quirks accompany the quick-witted dialogue that progresses the film from opening through credits.

Other Wes Anderson staples, such as cameos and select roles from a familiar cast of characters (a laundry list of talent), are present, some of which you will wish had a larger role in this very intelligent story. All-in-all The Grand Budapest Hotel is a thoroughly impressive effort that deserved the veneration it has received thus far.

     As usual this movie too a comedy with director's traditional actors in it. A comedy that set in the backdrop of a hotel theme and their employees. This hotel is called 'The Grand Budapest Hotel' located on the edge of the Alp mountain in a fictional EU country Zubrowska. The story proceeds with the two layers of flashback to the years 1968 and 1932. It unfolds the life story of Gustave, prestigious hotel's caretaker and his pupil Zero, a lobby boy. Theirs struggle over the accusation of a crime and the other side world war is on a verge to invade the nation. Whether they successful to defend against the charges or not is the remaining story speaks.

     Nice story and performances with eye catching visuals. Easily one of the best of this year. It looks very ordinary if it was a usual style movie, but Wes Anderson's touch made all the differences. The adventures are the highlights in all of his movies and so in this movie. Lots of whites and pinks you can see on the screen which is kind of trademark of this movie. In this humour movie violence partially attached, but safely avoided all the cruelties. With the lend of Saoirse Ronan character the story exploits a little bit youthful romance side. The introduction of other characters in the middle of the storytelling made more venturesome in the later parts.

     I kind of doubt to suggest it if you are unfamiliar with Wes Anderson's earlier works. You should better start with them before committing this movie. There's a reason, because you may not indulge it like my friend who saw this with me who never hear the director. Otherwise, it is..., of course it is another masterwork by Wes. Anyway, I loved it and waiting for his new project announcement.

Wes Anderson's best film since "The Royal Tenebaums". Anderson, an over-hyped, self-pleased director, has never been a favorite of mine, but "The Grand Budapest Hotel" is colorful and entertaining with a great performance from Ralph Fiennes. Tonally a bit all over the place but still good fun.

One line summary: Funny, touching, bizarre, and well worth the watch.

----------------------------------------------------
We start the film with an Author, in his later years, doing a video recording.  He then promises to tell the audience how he came to know a particular story.

We switch back to 1968, when the Young Writer was staying at the Grand Budapest Hotel, which was in its fading, twilight years.  The Young Writer meets Mr. Moustafa, who tells him the story of how he came to own the Grand Budapest Hotel.

We switch back to 1932; the new Lobby Boy (Zero) begins his tutelage with M. Gustave.  Gustave likes older, rich, blonde women, and he romances them.  In particular, Madame D. is quite fond of him.  She is on a trip, and has a presentiment of death.  Sure enough, she dies in the town where she traveled to.  Gustave and Zero hurry to see her, and are there in time to hear the reading of the will.  The surprise is that she willed the priceless painting 'Boy with Apple' to Gustave.  The family is furious, and Gustave is accused of her murder, but not before Zero and he secreted the painting.

Mr. Moustafa pauses to describe his relationship to Agatha, who works in the bakery of the hotel.  Agatha helps in the escape of Mr. Gustave.  Then Moustafa returns to the investigation of Madame D's death, and the process of bringing the probate to a legally sound close.

Mr. Gustave, with the aid of Zero and four fellow prisoners, escapes prison.  Gustave reaches for help from his fellow concierge friends.

In the counter-theme, Dmitri and his cohort Jopling, pursue Gustave for the sake of the painting, mostly.

Will anyone find Serge, supposedly the real culprit in the death of Madame D. ?   Do we get to know how Zero gets enough money to buy the Grand Budapest?  Will Zero and Agatha ever get together legally?  What will become of Dmitri and Jopling?  Will Henckles re-capture Gustave or Zero?

-----Scores-----
Cinematography: 10/10 Fine job.

Sound: 10/10 Well done.  Sometimes wildly inappropriate but usually good for a laugh or two.

Acting: 10/10  What a cast!  Great jobs by most involved.  No bad performances.

Screenplay: 6/10 The main plot is so stupid it is beyond belief, but one assumes that was on purpose.  I got several belly laughs, dozens of smiles, and double handful of chuckles.

A really, really clever film that represents all the strange beauties of Wes Anderson's auteur cinema - from the bizarre yet lovely characters, surreal settings, to the sentimental ambiance, all wrapped up in a deeply interesting plot of many layers, many twist-and-turns (never seen such complexity before in Wes Anderson's films), and much humanity. A delightful film to watch, but somehow I still feel some degree of emotional detachment, which makes the (quite suddenly) sentimental remarks by the old Zero at the end not as effective as I expected. Well, maybe that is the intention of Wes Anderson after all - making a film for the audience to enjoy (and indeed it is enjoyable, and hugely popular - as a Wes Anderson film) and not to frown (I prefer The Royal Tenenbaums in this aspect - a film that can balance both). It's good to see Wes Anderson still keeps up his spirit after all those years.

More fast paced and swiftly acted than most Wes Anderson movies, this is almost like a chase film set in the mountains. The most 'Wes Anderson' of all the Wes Anderson films and that is no bad thing. Brilliant direction and set design along with superb performances and over the top qwerkyness.

With The Grand Budapest Hotel, Anderson gives us a rollicking comedy about a hotel concierge (Fiennes) who is framed for the murder of a wealthy guest (Swinton) who has left him a fortune.  With the help of his trusty lobby boy (Revolori) he must escape prison and clear his name, just as Europe falls into war. You pretty much should know what you will be getting in terms of tone with a Wes Anderson movie, and this is no exception. The star studded cast are all very entertaining to watch (in small and large roles alike), and the production design is a triumph of style and colours, as is Alexander Desplat's breathlessly peppy score - but, for a movie that behaves like a comedy, instances of laughter are actually not so many, and the whole affair borders on caricature so often, the potential drama inherent to the story is diffused, and  the anachronistic expletive laden dialogue and occasional attempts  at  visceral violence are no compensation for it.

With his classic quirk, sublime cast and visual panache Anderson manages to pull off another one for the books. Almost flawless, The Grand Budapest Hotel manages to be a fantastic movie that meanders all over the place but never fails to captivate every fiber of the viewer's attention.

Satirical genius!  Absolutely loved it!  Has a slapstick feel to the "action sequences" and it almost felt like watching an old silent film at times.  Probably the best fun I've had watching a movie in quite some time.  Well done!
Drags at time but full of style I like.
Moves along fluently and carefully, every actor plays their role perfectly in particular Ralph Fiennes who gives one of his best performances. Possibly my favourite Wes Anderson film.

It's beautiful, the characters are engaging and it tells a story you haven't heard a thousand times before. If you don't like Wes Anderson, I think that is a sign that you have mental issues. Seriously. For instance, I was reading the negative reviews from other non-critics like Alice Shen and she obviously has some problems. Before you jump to the conclusion that Alice just doesn't like W.A., you should note that she gives a very high rating to Darjeeling Limited. At first I assumed that it was just be a matter of 'taste', but upon further examination I noticed that she gave Silver Linings Playbook and Goonies 1-star as well, and called goonies stupid or something to that effect. Among her 2-star selections for Alice are The Departed and American Hustle--this is upsetting and is what led me to write this counter-comment. Of course there is no incorrectness to a subjective review--A clown can be funny or scary depending on your point of view--but the star gauge that is shorthand for a movie's empirical quality can be incorrect and is downright wrong in many of Alice Shen's critiques. My point is that the stars allocated to movies should be relative between reviews for each critic. If Alice really thinks this movie along with goonies and those other oscar winning ones are relatively worse than some of her 3-star selections (spring breakers, don jon, from justin to kelly, the bling ring, not another teen movie, etc) than she is truly wasting her time writing reviews and embarrassing herself by exposing this warped 'taste'. Alice, you gave 4 stars to Ella Enchanted, Dirty Dancing and Rent, what's up with that? I admit that I haven't ever been able to sit through any of those movies for more than a few minutes, but I'm confident they weren't going to become good movies at any point. Maybe it is taste, but if so, you do not have any and should not publicly express this shortcoming 900+ times. TL;DR: Wes Anderson is an artist and deserves better than crap comments.
